I for one don't want to teach either my son or my daughter that dynamic.



I want my son to respect women and not expect sex from his lady after only a couple of dates. That's a problem, you know - I've heard quite a few men say that if a woman won't sleep with them after a couple of dates they will dump her. Nice. That's not the kind of male I wish my son to be. I want him to value sex enough to see that it is worth waiting for and saving for marriage. I want him to respect himself enough to wait.



I want my daughter to respect her body instead of treating it like a bargaining chip to get attention or things. I want her to remember that she is worth more than that. I want her, like my son, to value sex enough to want to save it for her husband and herself alone. I want her to respect her young man when she has one, too.



I want this for their sakes. Hubby does too. We both agree that this is the best thing for them, after seeing how wonderfully it worked out for us. It makes a huge difference in life.



IMO this whole sexual dynamic society has today is based on a lack of respect. People don't respect themselves or each other. If they did they wouldn't be jumping into bed with near strangers all the time.

<answer>



I'm not obsessed with disconnecting it. I'm obsessed with ceasing to force people to be what they are not, for some arbitrary societal standard.



Why is it so threatening to you that people don't stick to their pre-defined gender pigeon-holes?



In the 18th century, upper-class men wore make-up and tight satin pants and minced around in high-heels. Gender behavior is ever-changing, not human law.

<answer from>



Elf #3
Member since: 24 November 2006
Total points: 15661 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Because I don't want to be prohibited from certain activities or certain jobs simply because my body has breasts and a vagina.



For example, I have lots of trees in my yard, and when Ike ripped through, there were lots of downed branches.  I got out my chain saw and cleaned up the mess.  This is usually considered man's work because it requires moderate upper body strength.  But I have a saw that is scaled to for my size and strength and enjoy the exercise.



This is a purely personal example, but when most of society is entrenched in gender roles, both women and men have limited employment opportunities.



Firefighters are a good example, because most people use the argument of dragging a person out of a burning building.  But what about the other essential functions of a fire fighting team?  Aren't there roles where women can serve just as effectively as men?



By separating sex and gender, we get to choose roles rather than having them assigned by default.



</answer>



<answer from>

Total points: 330 (Level 2)

<answer from>



Celebrating the feminine (Char)
Member since: 17 October 2007
Total points: 9224 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Modern feminism is essentially a movement for people who don't fit gender roles. I don't mind that - it's good to see people as individuals and try to accept them for their personal qualities, and I don't think anyone should be denied opportunities because of their gender.



But I wish they'd understand that many studies have shown a biological origin to gender identity, and that they are the exception to the rules. Most feminist theorists believe that differences create social division, which isn't true at all; a gender neutral society isn't needed to have equality. Sex and gender are different, but in the majority of people they go alongside each other; that's not stereotyping, it's biological fact.



</answer>

</question>

THAT is why so many women have decided that they hate men.  So don't start complaining about a modern feminist hating you if you come face to face with one.



So Raj, you believe that men should be allowed to be total whores, but women shouldn't?  Please explain.



Kurishi, I have no idea what you're talking about.  Elaborate more on the housework and childrearing thing, or else you're getting a thumbs down.

<answer from>



That's Right! I'm Raj!
Member since: 26 September 2008
Total points: 47 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I have no problem with any of those, because those are simply matters of self-direction EXCEPT for the concepts of "equality", equal respect and equal pay for the following reasons:



Equality: Men and women are equal in terms of their human worth. But they are not "equal" in that they are the same (because contrary to feminist madness, equality does equal sameness). This concepts also leads to other follies like the pursuit of material equality (i.e. communism) and vice.



Equal pay: This is a myth and can only be achieved through labor-market price fixing (which is basically communism or socialism). It is not only unjust (since external bodies arbitrarily determine your pay, rather than you), but it's economically disastrous.



Equal Respect: This is a nebulous and silly thing that results in all sorts of social calamity. It justifies abortion (such that women can be free of the burden of childbirth, just like men), promiscuity (such that women, who are the guardians of chastity, join men in pursuing sex), and, in general, a treatment of women that is contradictory to their nature.



Edit: Last I checked, sex required both men and women to occur (at least normal sex does). So how can a man be a "whore" without a corresponding woman "whore"? Men are more sexually aggressive and pursue sex more by their nature than women. If women do the same, then a lot more sex (and abortions and out-of-wedlock births and divorces) simply occurs. If women lived up to their responsibilities as guardians of their chastity (and since feminists say that it's "their body", it is therefore "their responsibility"), we would all be much better off.



Edit 2: Men SHOULD be chaste. But, just by human nature, men pursue and women are pursued (even in this feminist world we live in). If you tell women that they should be just as pursuant as men (which is contradictory to human nature), then women are more willing to abandon their role as guardians of their chastity. Now we have neither group that lives up to this role, which has resulted in a lot more sex and the various social calamities that arise from it.



Edit 3: I think it's good to avoid masterbation (this goes back to arguments over lust and it's overriding effects on the mind and the will), but it's irrelevant as far as social ills go so I don't really care one way or the other. You can't get pregnant, transmit an STD or cause emotional damage to somebody else through self-gratification.



</answer>



<answer from>



Eoghan.
Member since: 28 July 2008
Total points: 2051 (Level 3)

<answer from>



falet
Member since: 21 June 2008
Total points: 302 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



respect: they already do- *when deserved* - more respect than men in fact. respect in our culture comes from (1) being an expert (most leading scientists and nobel laureates are men) and (2) having very high moralities (women when caring and charitable make inroads here) and (3) being courageous/bold (a quality usually found more in men)



equal pay: already do (in the US at least). if education fields (engingeering, management, sciences always pays much more), time off, maternity and other concessions are taken into account fully. There's a lot of controversy on this and you'll find statistics both ways. There was an interesting class at Harvard U on the economics of gender last semester (Im not a student there- but saw the syllabus and read part of the book)



educated: in the US, women already outnumber men on college campuses. There is absolutely NO barrier to a woman getting educated.For engineering, math and science, there is unusual support and desire for women students and researchers, shown by special fellowships and scholarships available to them only.



houseword/childrearing: this has since the beginning of civilization been the domain of the mother- to nurture and protect her child. women will always be more involved with raising and nurturing their children. men are rarely as attached to their child. that said, most people do agree that when both parents are working, men should help more. in reality this rarely happens. success depends on the individual household rather than the society at large. expect changes in the following decades but not complete 50/50.



</answer>

<question from>



EW
Member since: 03 January 2008
Total points: 35 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Differences in values and beliefs with gender?



Although values and beliefs are intrinsically very personal, they are also "formed" by societal conditioning, peer pressure etc.



Which core beliefs and values do you think are DIFFERENT between the genders. Do you agree that we probably share more in terms of values and beliefs than we differ?



</question>



<answer from>



Abra B
Member since: 21 December 2007
Total points: 3216 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think men and women of the same culture probably have more values and beliefs in common than two people of the same sex of different cultures.  Very few values seem to be intrinsic, most are taught by religious, political, societal system.  From what I've studied, taboos against murder and incest seem to be the most common across cultures.  That stated, there will be some common threads ... look at worldwide campaigns to stop injustice, etc.



For instance, a worldwide campaign to help women in poverty isn't necessarily a "woman" thing.  It's that women have tended to be oppressed historically in many cultures, stemming from the fact that they are the physically weaker sex and physical strength has been the defining characteristic of power in older times.  Women often mutually understand the feeling of being oppressed, so they may reach out to help each other.



But its not exclusive to women -- other demographics that feel oppressed may also pitch in.  Consider the Civil Rights Movement, and how it was aided by other minority groups such as women, homosexuals, etc.  Eventually, many movements took place -- which leads me to believe that we have a general human drive for dignity and equality.



Source(s):



sorry, a bit rambling



</answer>



<answer from>



R. Gaspari
Member since: 10 July 2008
Total points: 7060 (Level 5)

Gender & Women's Studies

</answer from>

Abortion is not infanticide unless the fetus in question is viable or able to live outside of its mother.



Most women do not choose abortion lightly.  Rape, incest, health, lack of economic resources are some reasons women choose to abort.  In a perfect world every child would be wanted, women would not be raped, and every woman would be healthy enough to carry a pregnancy to term.  But we do not live in a perfect world.



Better access to reproductive services, birth control, and sex education has been proven to reduce the amount of abortions. Hopefully you are on board with this.  Criminalizing abortion may have reduced abortion but with the terrible consequence of women performing abortions on themselves or going to "back alley" abortionists putting their health and lives at risk.



When I was young I read a book that talked about the days before it was legal.  I remember a black and white picture of a girl, slumped over and dead on a floor from a botched abortion.  That image is seared in my mind forever and that's why I'm pro choice today.  I don't EVER want to go back to those days.  Do you?

Now, sex based abortion is simply wrong.



It is deciding that one life, because of its gender, is more important than the other. I despise people who support that way of thinking. A male is no more important than a female, and vise versa. How would you like it, if you couldn't find a husband or wife for your child, because of selective abortion?



Also, would you really want to raise your children to believe that one gender is better than the other ? I mean, if there is gender based abortion, your children would eventually ask why, wouldn't they? Think of China- how do you think those girls feel, knowing  every single day of their existence, that  they are worthless, and because boys are the prized creatures, the girls must be the servants, because girls have no value? How do you think they feel, when they know that they are viewed as 'nothings' and 'burdens to society'. And those are the girls who were allowed to live. Would you want that same view of life spread throughout our country? I know I wouldn't. I'd want my children to respect life equally and to learn right from wrong as we have always done.



This sex based abortion has the potential to create a monster.



How would you like it if we had a situation on our hands like China? They killed their baby girls for years, because they saw no value in them. Now they don't have an even ratio of males to females, hence, not enough wives for their sons. And you know what? It serves them right! No matter which gender is deemed 'more important' it is wrong, and it could spin out of control.



</answer>

<question from>



R. Gaspari
Member since: 10 July 2008

Contributing In:



Gender & Women's Studies



Medicine



</question from>



<question>



Gentlemen, if you were in a hiring position and the candidate's resume...?



Revealed that one of the organizations with which the candidate is affiliated is a modern Feminist organization would you consider interviewing this candidate?



If a CV or resume serves as the basis for determining whether a candidate is suitable, there's a lot of subjectivity in deciding if you'd like to interview them.



If the candidate indicates that the candidate is a member of an unsavory organization like the KKK or a modern Feminist organization which I find makes the candidate unsuitable for the job, I believe that I'm entitled to take this into consideration and throw the resume in the trash bin or "keep it on file" as they say, (this doesn't represent gender discrimination).



Would you also be reluctant to interview a candidate that is a member of an unsavory organization like the KKK, Aryan Nation or a Feminist organization?



</question>



<answer from>



Holly
Member since: 25 January 2007
Total points: 6370 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Political affiliation is not covered under the federal employment laws.  So I would say you have the right to not hire this person based on the fact that their political affiliations are "unsavory" to you.



Sigh...again with the thumbs down for merely stating the unbiased truth.



Source(s):



Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (Title VII), which prohibits employment discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, or national origin;



the Equal Pay Act of 1963 (EPA), which protects men and women who perform substantially equal work in the same establishment from sex-based wage discrimination;



the Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967 (ADEA), which protects individuals who are 40 years of age or older;



Title I and Title V of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (ADA), which prohibit employment discrimination against qualified individuals with disabilities in the private sector, and in state and local governments;



Sections 501 and 505 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, which prohibit discrimination against qualified individuals with disabilities who work in the federal government;



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thank you.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Rio Madeira
Member since: 11 March 2007
Total points: 66888 (Level 7)



</answer from>

If it was an organization I disagreed with but didn't consider dangerous, it would be the least of my concerns.



</answer>

<question>



Since "feminism" is so etymologically similar to "dwarfism" or "gigantism"...?



why doesn't feminism actually mean "the condition of being feminine"? Why does it actually mean the opposite (i.e. the feminine adopting masculine attributes)? An "ism" is a doctrine governing the word before it, and the word before "ism" is "feminine". Is this just more proof that "feminists" (or should they be called "masculinists") have no idea what they're talking about?



http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/d...
http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/g...
http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/i...

most parents only worry about their daughter doing so since their girls might get involved with wild-nightout people and dangerous men.



----but why musn't them worry at all about their sons, not even about what their sons can do outside at late night, while it's actually easier for boys to get influence with gangsterism and drugs (compared to girls) ? plus, it will keep the boys loitering while they should have sleep or at least studying. this would affect their performance, and this is actually the thing that can make the boys to be more useless than girls. in the end, more boys will dig the girls' golds.

it's like a disgrace when girls can't cook well. they say "don't be a woman if you can't cook" (wt...?). also the stereotype that "girls place are in kitchen". it's ok if they say that when the boys are in wars, but why is it still the same even when the boys are on couch?



there are multiple questions here, actually. but the point is, why can't parents treat both sons and daughter at least a little more equally, since daughters are too constrained while the boys are too freed? i know that it has something to do with boys can take care of themselves thing. however, although their sons might be male, they are kids too, so they're young yet immatured that they can always do stupid and disgraceful things. but why do these parents don't seem to have any thoughts about that?

You're a mean one, Mr. Grinch.
You really are a heel.
You're as cuddly as a cactus,
You're as charming as an eel.
Mr. Grinch.



You're a bad banana
With a greasy black peel.



You're a monster, Mr. Grinch.
Your heart's an empty hole.
Your brain is full of spiders,
You've got garlic in your soul.
Mr. Grinch.



I wouldn't touch you, with a



thirty-nine-and-a-half foot pole.



You're a vile one, Mr. Grinch.
You have termites in your smile.
You have all the tender sweetness
Of a seasick crocodile.
Mr. Grinch.



Given the choice between the two of you
I'd take the seasick crockodile.



You're a foul one, Mr. Grinch.
You're a nasty, wasty skunk.
Your heart is full of unwashed socks
Your soul is full of gunk.
Mr. Grinch.



The three words that best describe you,
are, and I quote: "Stink. Stank. Stunk."



You're a rotter, Mr. Grinch.
You're the king of sinful sots.
Your heart's a dead tomato splot
With moldy purple spots,
Mr. Grinch.



Your soul is an apalling dump heap overflowing
with the most disgraceful assortment of deplorable
rubbish imaginable,
Mangled up in tangled up knots.



You nauseate me, Mr. Grinch.
With a nauseaus super-naus.
You're a crooked jerky jockey
And you drive a crooked horse.
Mr. Grinch.



You're a three decker saurkraut and toadstool
sandwich
With arsenic sauce.



</answer>

I tell him 6000 or bust, because I don't see why I should work my butt off for projects that earn him hundreds of thousands and settle for chump change.
He wails, but in the end agrees, because it aint like he can go and pick a programmer out of a soup line.



What should happen according to the feminists ?



- nothing everybody works for what she/he signed up for

- both our salaries should be averaged so both earn the same



- something else ??

I agree that men are regarded with suspicion, I disagree that it's fair. A while ago I remember walking down the street with a hoody on, a group of girls were coming in my direction. Most guys avoid children altogether, I take holiday programmes at the moment, one of the activities involves tying medals around the necks of 7 year olds. I have to be extremely careful not to accidently touch them while doing this - which is pretty difficult I assure you - or risk being held under suspicion by the women around me. Is it much wonder that men avoid teaching in primary schools?



Just look at how easy it is to falsely accuse men of child abuse, voilence and rape. Things like VAWA and Harman's bill which is going to be introduced soon; these both are products of mistrust towards men.

<original file>3771.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk26719.txt</current file name>




<category>



Social Science



Gender & Women's Studies



</category>



<question from>



Rachel
Member since: 08 November 2006
Total points: 1018 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



What would you think of her?



A young woman you work with has really bad asthma and was taken to the hospital for it earlier this year. But she's pretty shy and soft-spoken so she doesn't talk about it unless someone wants to check up on her. Occasionally while she's quietly working, you will hear her cough a lot, sometimes with a loud wheeze. When she came in the other day, she mentioned how she had a rough night. She said an attack hit after midnight, she didn't go to sleep until 1AM and then was up every few hours in the middle of the night. When she was at work, she seemed tired, but throughout the day functioned pretty normally and seemed her quiet, hard-working, smiley self.



What would u think of her?



</question>



<answer from>



Patrick
Member since: 25 August 2008
Total points: 1778 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>

R. Gaspari

Contributing In:

Medicine

<answer>



I think that she's not either not complying with her asthma medications or is not being treated properly.  I would implore that she immediately see a proper physician (if she's not being treated properly) and be placed on something like Advair or some combination of corticosteroid plus a beta agonist, e.g. salmeterol or and always have a rescue inhaler of albuterol present.



The public may not see this but when asthma goes untreated and a young patient arrives at the hospital already cyanotic, all the neubulizer treaments & epi in the world won't help, these patients die.  I've had to watch children die because they weren't being adequately treated for asthma.  My concern would be for her health first and foremost.



</answer>

<question from>



Kurushi

Total points: 818 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Has there ever been statistics released on male victims of rape by a female perpetrator ?



</question>



<additional details>



if so could you please provide links?



Hi Blackburner -



"Non statutory female on male rape is widely, but incorrectly, considered impossible because male erectile response is seen as voluntary, when, in fact, it is involuntary. Fear, anger, anxiety, and non-arousal have been cited as factors in being unable to obtain an erection. Therefore, male victims of rape by females often face social, political, and legal double standards. Female rapists are usually seen as less culpable than male rapists by the courts due to these misunderstandings. Those who do not understand the law in many jurisdictions fail to realize that the penetration of a male by a foreign object or a digit also constitutes the same crime. Since rape by females is much less well known than male-female rape, male victims of female rapists often find little support from rape crisis centers."



</additional details>

<answer from>



thebug

<answer>



Jackson Katz says that 99.8% of people convicted of rape in prison are male:



http://uk.youtube.com/watch?v=3exzMPT4nG...



That would put femle perpetrated rape at 0.2%, but of course if there is really such a taboo about male victims of rape perpetrated by women, then the stats of successful conviction rates won't reveal it.



My guess is that female on male rape is so rare, that it would be a waste of resources to fund special rape crisis centres for them- it would require paying for staff who would have very little to do, especially when (in the uk at least ) funding is already being taken away from rape crisis centres for women. In London there is only one rape crisis centre - well- its in Croydon - which is very far south of London - no where near the centre.



I've had male friends confess to me that they've been raped by men, female friends confess that they've been raped by men (only 1 has reported it to the police), but never been told of a male friend raped by a woman. I have assessed that a female friend of mine sexually assaulted another woman, which she denies, but the way she explained events, it definately seemed that way, so I also wonder if in that 0.2% rape stat of Jackson Katz whether that includes female upon female assault.



To state it plainly, a man is far more likely to be a victim of rape by another man than by a women. However, I do not think we should trivialise it, because rape is about power, violence, violation, humiliation,etc. If we look to the Gulf War pics with Lindy England mockng the prisoners who they had obviously forced to arouse themselves, its clear that this physiological response can occur in terrifying, humiliating circumstances.



</answer>

<answer>



Well, I have never been a mother at all, but I hold a great deal of respect for those who are. It looks like extremely hard work.



And how can you discipline a baby to clean its own room and do chores? Your question states that you are talking about babies, but you fail to realise that a baby is a lot of hard work. Cleaning the baby, feeding, playing with, socialising, changing...



Not everyone has a husband who can help them around the house either - maybe he works long late hours and is exhausted. If you are going to be a stay-at-home-mother, you are accepting the responsibility for the majority of housework as well as childcare. If both parents work, of course they should share the chores, but if only the man works, why should he have to do chores as well? That's unfair.



"You get to stay home, be with your kid 24/7, free food, free transportation, free home/stay, your office is the sofa , escape from the rat race, and many more positives" - you really are looking down on these women as if they were lazy or something. There's nothing lazy about cleaning and cooking and of all the mothers I know, not one spends all day on the sofa. Nor is anything "free". If you are married or co-habiting, you have accepted that you are together, you are working together as a team. That means sharing and accepting that what is one partner's also belongs to the other person. She isn't scrounging off her partner, her partner is sharing with her and what's his is her's and vice versa - you don't understand the nature of relationships.



I think from the tone of your question that you resent having to work and you resent that other women are free to spend more time with their children.



</answer>

Louise C
Member since: 09 January 2008
Total points: 43790 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



History



Books & Authors



Gender & Women's Studies



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't find being a housewife particularly hard, but I think some women work harder at it than I do.



However, I don't see how you can cook 2 nights a week only.  do you mean you should freeze a lot of stuff?  We haven't got a big enough freezer for that, and in any case I don't think my husband would care to eat frozen food every night.



As far as getting children to help with chores goes, I have never managed to get my sons to do that, but I suppose there are some women who can manage it.



I don't clean the whole house every day, as I find housework quite boring, I just do a bit of the house every day.



It is a lot easier when the children are at school, as you have several hours a day to do everything in peace.



However, if you have two children under school age (as I did for a while) then it is VERY tiring.  Looking after very small children is exhuasting, and two at once can wear you out very quickly.  It doesn't have to be more than two to exhaust you.



However, I certainly don't think it is harder work than being in a regular job, and that as far as I am concerned is one of the advantages. If I fel that I worked harder than a person who is out at work all day then it would have a lot less appeal to me.



I think the reason modern housewives tend to go on and on and on about how hard they work is that nowadays we are all supposed to WANT to work really hard all the time.  endless toil is supposed to be the goal of all of us.  The days when those who had least work to do were considered the most fortunate are long gone.  Nowadays, you are supposed to want to work all the time, without ceasing, and if you don;'t you are considered somewhat peculiar. I think this is why housewives have a tendency to insist on the hardness of their lives.  They've got to prove that they are toiling all day just like everyone is supposed to nowadays.



</answer>

Member since: 04 August 2008

<answer>



Cooking 2 nights a week? We don't like eating the same meal for 3 or 4 days in a row. If you do, fine. Go for it. I don't. I like something different. Cooking's not hard. I don't mind doing it daily.



Free food? LOL um, someone pays good money for all the food we eat! What, you think we steal our food from the grocery store every week? LOL Ditto with transportation and "home/stay". I'm involved with my church. Not work.....whatever.



Being a SAHM is work. <question>



Why does a guy have to play "prince charming" to get a one night stand?



Why do guys have to play "prince charming" to get girls to bed?
My friend Kim (20) told me what she had experienced at a gig two months ago. She had met this guy there and he asked her out after the gig. She told me that they exchanged interests and got to know each other. She thought they had good chemistry. Two hours later (that night) they kissed. Kim told me he was romantic and everything. He held her hand, stroked her, bought her a drink etc. They weren't drunk and they only drank 1 or 2 beer each. She told me he confused her very much. He played on the "prince charming" image and he still said she reminded him of a porn star. And they still held an intelligent conversation. Kim told me that he suggested that they should go into a toilet! (and presumably have sex). She said that she was unsure about what he wanted. She isn't a "gatekeeper" and she doesn't see anything wrong with one night stands, sex on the first date etc. She doesn't like the socially accepted fact that girls have to play it hard and be "gatekeerpers". She isn't guilty about anything but she is very sad because she felt this guy was an interesting person who had much in common with her. She told me they could just be friends and nothing more. She was disappointed. This guy played on many things to get her attention: friendship, "prince charming tendency", romance, dirty talk, intelligent conversations and debates, getting to know her etc.
They didn't have sex but they made out and she told me she was looking forwards to seeing this guy again. She sent him SMS (2 times) and he didn't answer her. She gave up. Why did this guy bother getting to know her if he wasn't interested in nothing more than sex? Why did he act romantic? Why did he come with the intelligent debates? Why couldn't he rather have played dirty and lusty instead of tricking her into believing he wanted a relationship? Why couldn't he be honest. I think I would prefer a guy who said "I just want to have a one night stand" to a guy who showed interest in my personality and then wouldn't talk to me again. I think most people value honesty. Why couldn't he have been honest with her? This is in 2008 and a guy does not have to play "prince charming" to get a one night stand. He was indeed playing "prince confusing".
Fellow girls/women, can you always tell if a guy wants just sex or something more?



</question>



<additional details>



I find the "toilet" thing weird too. But she did make it clear that this guy was very confusing. He was first playing on getting to knowing her, then romance and then naughtiness+romance++++++++++



Kris W, she is not blaming anyone. It is not about blaming men. If a woman was using a man I would have reacted the same way. If a woman was playing interested in him only to get him into bed.



</additional details>

<answer>



Generally speaking, very few women (and, to speak more broadly, very few people in general) are open to casual, semi-anonymous sex with recently-met partners, for good reason; there's a strong correlation between people who don't take to one-night-stands and people who don't have some version of the herpes virus.



But, for that reason, people who DO seek that sort of sex tend to recognize the need to put on costumes to 'broaden their market,' so to speak, or else meet with very rare success.  As a result, most people (male and female) seeking one-night-stands have a tendency to pretend not to be, and often a tendency to refuse to even admit to themselves what they're doing (most one-night-standers I know tend to describe their experiences as "being swept up in things" and "before-I-knew-it"s rather than calculated efforts to get their partners into bed).



</answer>

<answer>



Yes, the masculine is demonised in the feminist controlled education, social services and family related legal systems, but I don't believe it began at the birth of feminism. I agree with Mary McElroy......



"Genuine discussion of feminist issues ended in the 1970s when one school came to dominate and moved to silence competing views both within the movement and outside.



Politically correct feminists maintain that women as a class are politically oppressed by men as a class, which means that every woman is oppressed by every man. Class oppression is the ideological lens through which PC feminism views all issues."



Mary is taking about when feminism shifted from being a human rights movement to being a propaganda spreading hate group.

<question>



Is bidirectional-rape possible?



Feminists say that, if a woman is drunk, then her consent is invalid (and she could therefore cry rape, even if she was willing when drunk). They also claim to want equality between the sexes, so I would think that the same would apply if the cases were reversed (i.e. if the man were drunk, then he could cry rape). What happens if both are drunk and they do the deed and both decide to cry rape? Can they each press charges against the other and show up to court as simultaneously the victims and perpetrators of rape?



</question>



<answer from>

Member since: 28 July 2008
Total points: 2036 (Level 3)

<question from>



That's Right! I'm Raj!
Member since: 26 September 2008

</question from>



<question>



Does modern feminist theory actually give men a free pass to rape women?



Before deleting this question, explain to me how modern feminist theory would approach the following scenario:



Suppose that a particularly lewd and licentious man spots a woman to whom is attracted. Having no morals, he decides to rape her. But before he does so, he downs a bottle of "liquid courage". After he commits his appalling crime, he is arrested. But it turns out that he was drunk at the time, and feminists claim that drunkenness (at least as far as women go) dissolves the consent. So apparently the rapist did not, according to feminists, consent to sex and could therefore claim that the woman raped him instead. Without violating the supposed feminist principles of equality, can somebody explain why this rapist, according the modern feminist theory, is actually a rapist?



</question>



<additional details>



Jenny: I don't understand. What does that mean exactly? That his consent was dissolved, but that he consented to aggression? Doesn't that mean he consented (contradicting feminist theory)?



And for the record, I think that such an act should result in many years behind bars. I just don't see how this is even a crime according to feminists.



Mr. Morbid: That's true, but from a practical perspective, there's no evidence and no reason for a jury to believe that he had planned his attack beforehand. Also, are you saying that if a woman desires a man (but doesn't sleep with him), then is later raped by him (in a feminist drunk way), then is that therefore consent?



To reiterate my record, I think it was a crime for which he should be punished, but I haven't seen any explanations that conform to feminists' opinion on the matter (pertaining to drunkennes and consent). Obviously most (including me) disagree that it was non-consensual, but I just can't see how, from a feminist perspective (and without abandoning their so-called egalitarian nature), that this could be a crime.



nickipettis: That's all fine and dandy, but a jury also needs evidence to support their decision, and there is no evidence of intent, so from a practical perspective, no intent can be shown. Also, feminists think that even if a woman intended to have sex with a man, she can claim rape if she has sex with him while drunk (because drunkenness invalidates the consent).



thingamabob: So this man is simply guilty of a less serious crime (neglect) than rape?



</additional details>



<answer from>



Jenny
Member since: 21 January 2007
Total points: 5226 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



dissolved consent doesn't equal dissolved aggression



</answer>



<answer from>



Mr. Morbid
Member since: 23 August 2007
Total points: 7163 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



"Having no morals, he decides to rape her. But before he does so, he downs a bottle of "liquid courage"."



In your scenario: he made the decision to commit the rape while sober (for one thing) and two, He forced himself on HER.... "consent" never even comes into the picture, and alcohol or drugs is not an acceptable excuse for a crime...



</answer>



<answer from>



wwpetcem...
Member since: 28 March 2007
Total points: 5639 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



He didn't need to give consent to the woman he was the instigator. He had already premeditated what he was going to do and took action to help him commit rape. So his judgment wasn't clouded.



Now if the woman had asked him to rape her if he was already intoxicated then the principle would apply.



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



What message does gender switching names send?



More girls are being named with what used to be considered more traditional boy names (like Ryan for example). As these names shift from boys names to unisex names, they become less used on boys and more used on girls to the point where they often end up more as girls names (like Ashley).



But now I've started to notice that in some cases people are asking/opening up to using/actually using what were considered more traditional girls names on boys.



I saw a question on another name site the other day asking about naming a girl Caleb or Michael, and naming a boy Ashley or Morgan.



What message do you think it sends to the children if you give your daughter a more traditionally masculine name than your son? Do you see this is a "bad" thing or not?



Emma



</question>



<answer from>



Tracey
Member since: 09 September 2008
Total points: 557 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



"Do you see this is a "bad" thing or not?"



I don't see it as a bad thing in the slightest. The more we can quit forcing people into the arbitrary and rigid rules of gender behavior, the better.



Source(s):



Level 2



</answer>



<answer from>



Kev
Member since: 16 July 2008
Total points: 1497 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>

<answer from>



Eoghan.
Member since: 28 July 2008
Total points: 2039 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



The original domestic violence movement was hijacked by pc feminists who cloud our thinking on violence... "covers men" not good enough Tracey, everyone deserves equal protection by the law and social services. We should not have groups that do not care for all groups equally involved in protective legislation.



"In 1971, Pizzey opened the first battered wives shelter in England, which she ran until 1982. Arguably, the Chiswick Family Rescue was the second domestic violence shelter in the world. Pizzey's book "Scream Quietly or the Neighbours Will Hear" (1974, out of print) was one of the first to explore and expose wife battering.



Today, the shelter Pizzey founded denies her entry; her name does not appear in its official history.



Pizzey's 'mistake' was to diverge from the theory of domestic violence that feminists at the time insisted dominate all discussion. She believed that men could also be the victims of domestic violence, and that women could be as violent toward their partners as men.



Pizzey's views put her on a collision course with PC feminists who, according to Pizzey's own published account of events, initiated a campaign of harassment and violence against her.



Pizzey described this harassment in an article she published in the Scotsman in 1999.



"Because of my opposition to the hijacking of the refuge movement, I was a target for abuse. Anywhere I spoke there was a contingent of screaming, heckling feminists waiting for me," Pizzey wrote. "Abusive telephone calls to my home, death threats and bomb scares, became a way of living for me and for my family. Finally, the bomb squad, asked me to have all my mail delivered to their head quarters."



One night, the family dog was killed.



Eventually, "exhausted and disillusioned," Pizzey said she went into "exile with her children and grandchildren," leaving England in 1982 to live in Santa Fe, New Mexico.



Pizzey returned to England that same year for the book tour of her next book, "Prone to Violence," which once again ignited a violent reaction among feminists. Pizzey wrote that when she arrived in England for her book tour, she was "met with a solid wall of feminist demonstrators" carrying signs that read "ALL MEN ARE RAPISTS, ALL MEN ARE BATTERERS."



"The police insisted that I have an escort all round England for my book tour," Pizzey wrote in the Scotsman.



There is some reason to believe that "Prone to Violence" has been the target of a campaign of suppression by PC feminists. According to the web site Wikepedia, in 1996 an internet search of the world libraries that can be accessed through the Library of Congress uncovered only 13 listings for the book: an astonishingly low number for a pioneering work that caused a sensation.



Why would PC feminists nearly riot over a book and, then, ignore it?



Because Pizzey advanced a competing theory of domestic violence.



When viewed through the PC lens of class oppression, domestic violence is not an act of violence committed by one individual against another. It is an act committed by men that must be correctly understood within the larger context of women's class oppression.



"Prone to Violence" spelled out some of Pizzey's disagreements with that view.



Disagreement #1: Of the first 100 women who entered Chiswick, Pizzey found that over 60 percent were as violent or more violent than the men they were fleeing. In short, a significant percentage of the women were also batterers or otherwise active participants in the violence.



Disagreement #2: Pizzey developed the theory that many battered women were psychologically drawn to abusive relationships and they sought them out. To PC feminists, such analysis was tantamount to 'blaming the victim.'



Disagreement #3: She explained why the existing model of domestic violence shelters was ineffective. PC feminists were attempting then (and now) to secure ever greater financing for these operations. Sandra Horley, director of Chiswick in 1992, reportedly complained, "if we put across this idea that the abuse of men is as great as the abuse of women, then it could seriously affect our funding."



Pizzey may or may not have been correct; I believe she was and is.



Neverthless, her book drew upon over 10 years at the Chiswick shelter during which time Pizzey dealt with some 5,000 women and children.



"Prone to Violence" is an extremely early and honest overview of domestic violence from a woman with extensive experience of its daily realities. The book cried out to be taken seriously. At minimum, it deserved a thorough rebuttal from its PC feminist critics--not death threats directed at its author nor the ultimate silence it received.



Pizzey is not alone. In America, Suzanne Steinmetz -- author of the book "The Battered Husband" and a co-author of the much-cited "First National Family Violence Survey" -- experienced a similar drama. She and her children received death threats; an ACLU meeting at which she spoke received a bomb threat.



The reason: her research indicated that the rate at which men were victimized by domestic violence was similar to the rate for women.



In large and small ways -- from shrill protests to the tearing down of announcements, from blocking university promotions to threats and defamation -- PC feminism has attempted to stop voices it could not control.



Feminism is dying not from a backlash but from an orthodoxy that cannot tolerate real discussion...and never could."



Wendy McElroy is the editor of ifeminists.com and a research fellow for The Independent Institute in Oakland, Calif. She is the author and editor of many books and articles, including the new book, "Liberty for Women: Freedom and Feminism in the 21st Century" (Ivan R. Dee/Independent Institute, 2002). She lives with her husband in Canada.



</answer>



<answer from>



Lexie
Member since: 04 August 2008
Total points: 52 (Level 1)



</answer from>

</answer>

Tracey
Member since: 09 September 2008

<answer>



If a man is capable of standing, aiming and successfully punching someone in the face, he's not intoxicated to the point where informed consent disappears.



Informed consent disappears when a person is incapable of functioning. A man past this point would be laying on the barroom floor moaning or unconscious, not fighting.



</answer>

<answer>



Institutionalised chivalry, women are special. Loose definitions of rape also help those interested in exaggerating the prevalence or the crime.



Part of the general 'all men are rapists' attitude. The Independent Women's Forum maintains that this statistic is a myth: "based on a fallacious feminist study commissioned by Ms. magazine. The researcher, Mary Koss, hand-picked by hard-line feminist Gloria Steinem, acknowledges that 73 percent of the young women she counted as rape victims were not aware they had been raped. Forty-three percent of them were dating their 'attacker' again" http://www.massnews.com/2003_Editions/5_...



The general tactic has been to expand the definition of rape so as to make it seem more prevalent: "even verbal coercion or manipulation constitutes rape (Roiphe, 1993, pp. 6667) and with such a sweeping definition of rape, I wonder how many people there are, male or female, who havent been date-raped at one point or another (Roiphe, 1993, p. 79).  Dr. Christina Hoff Sommers observes: "Dr. Andrea Parrot, chair of the Cornell University Coalition Advocating Rape Education and author of Sexual Assault on Campus, begins her date rape prevention manual with the words, "Any sexual intercourse without mutual desire is a form of rape"http://www.leaderu.com/real/ri9502/...



Incredibly, when one feminist spokeswoman was challenged on the '1 in 4' statistic, she responded: "The statistics don't really matter... We're just trying to focus on the real issue here... not bicker about numbers" http://www.deltabravo.net/files/ifmenhav...

<question>



Something I don't understand about drunkenness and consent...?



if a woman has sex whilst drunk, she can cry rape. i.e. she isn't held responsible for her actions.



if a man punches someone in the face whilst drunk, he isn't able to escape an assault charge because he was drunk, because he made the choice to get drunk and is still responsible for his behaviour.



why is it ok to play the 'i was drunk' card if you're a woman, and not if you're a man?



</question>



<additional details>



Elf: you wouldnt call a false rape claim an act of violence?



</additional details>



<answer from>



Tracey
Member since: 09 September 2008
Total points: 571 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



If a man is capable of standing, aiming and successfully punching someone in the face, he's not intoxicated to the point where informed consent disappears.



Informed consent disappears when a person is incapable of functioning. A man past this point would be laying on the barroom floor moaning or unconscious, not fighting.



</answer>



<answer from>



Holly
Member since: 25 January 2007
Total points: 6481 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Its not ok in my book.  You made the choice to get drunk around someone you cant trust.  But then...thats how it works...nobody wants to take responsibility for their actions.



</answer>



<answer from>



Elf #3
Member since: 24 November 2006
Total points: 15657 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



The drunk man threw a punch and hurt someone else.



The drunk woman commited no act of violence against anyone else.



That said, I do not condone "playing the drunk card."
These cases should only be tried if there is hard evidence of intoxication (blood test) or the presence of rohypnol or other similar substances.



Edit: No, false rape charges would be an act of fraud, not violence.



</answer>

<answer from>



Eoghan.
Member since: 28 July 2008
Total points: 2045 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Institutionalised chivalry, women are special. Loose definitions of rape also help those interested in exaggerating the prevalence or the crime.



Part of the general 'all men are rapists' attitude. The Independent Women's Forum maintains that this statistic is a myth: "based on a fallacious feminist study commissioned by Ms. magazine. The researcher, Mary Koss, hand-picked by hard-line feminist Gloria Steinem, acknowledges that 73 percent of the young women she counted as rape victims were not aware they had been raped. Forty-three percent of them were dating their 'attacker' again" http://www.massnews.com/2003_Editions/5_...



The general tactic has been to expand the definition of rape so as to make it seem more prevalent: "even verbal coercion or manipulation constitutes rape (Roiphe, 1993, pp. 6667) and with such a sweeping definition of rape, I wonder how many people there are, male or female, who havent been date-raped at one point or another (Roiphe, 1993, p. 79).  Dr. Christina Hoff Sommers observes: "Dr. Andrea Parrot, chair of the Cornell University Coalition Advocating Rape Education and author of Sexual Assault on Campus, begins her date rape prevention manual with the words, "Any sexual intercourse without mutual desire is a form of rape"http://www.leaderu.com/real/ri9502/...



Incredibly, when one feminist spokeswoman was challenged on the '1 in 4' statistic, she responded: "The statistics don't really matter... We're just trying to focus on the real issue here... not bicker about numbers" http://www.deltabravo.net/files/ifmenhav...



Question: The above distortions of truth all have in common that they put men in a bad light. There are laws against incitement of prejudice against women and ethnic groups; should there be laws against incitement to promote prejudice against men? Or laws to prevent feminists covering up research that would help male victims of domestic violence?



Question: Do the media (e.g. BBC news) have an obligation to present information in a fair and balanced way, or is it ok for them to present only the story that the feminist movement wants us to hear?



</answer>

<answer>



Men & women standing side by side is similar to playing the piano with two hands in harmony.

To play the piano we're taught to match each hand to specific keys (notes).  We can try to make the right hand invert to play what the left hand has natural talent in with much practice.  However, the music becomes more beautiful, more harmonious, and more exciting when used as a pair instead of iscolating each hand.

Much like learning to play the piano, we (men & women) must study what goes where ... and listen to the music that's being created ... without fear of failure.  We mustn't stay in the same genre' of music if we're ever to grow and acheive greatness.  Imagine mastering "Twinkle - Twinkle Little Star" and never expanding on the possibilities?  How sad would that be? ;o(



</answer>

'If' by Rudyard Kipling

IF.....



--------------------------------------...



IF you can keep your head when all about you 
Are losing theirs and blaming it on you,
If you can trust yourself when all men doubt you,
But make allowance for their doubting too;
If you can wait and not be tired by waiting,
Or being lied about, don't deal in lies,
Or being hated, don't give way to hating,
And yet don't look too good, nor talk too wise:
If you can dream - and not make dreams your master;
If you can think - and not make thoughts your aim;
If you can meet with Triumph and Disaster
And treat those two impostors just the same;
If you can bear to hear the truth you've spoken
Twisted by knaves to make a trap for fools,
Or watch the things you gave your life to, broken,
And stoop and build 'em up with worn-out tools:



If you can make one heap of all your winnings 
And risk it on one turn of pitch-and-toss,
And lose, and start again at your beginnings
And never breathe a word about your loss;
If you can force your heart and nerve and sinew
To serve your turn long after they are gone,
And so hold on when there is nothing in you
Except the Will which says to them: 'Hold on!'

If you can talk with crowds and keep your virtue,
' Or walk with Kings - nor lose the common touch,
if neither foes nor loving friends can hurt you,
If all men count with you, but none too much;
If you can fill the unforgiving minute
With sixty seconds' worth of distance run,
Yours is the Earth and everything that's in it,
And - which is more - you'll be a Man, my son!



--------------------------------------...



</answer>

Ahh, thumbs down when I wasn't trolling?  To all of the people saying "work together", I point to history.  Change rarely ever is a product of two amorphous and massive sides coming to a compromise.  It is most often the result of a radical element of one side grabbing the sword and pushing forward.  If this element is strong enough, both sides will be forced to evolve the way they think to consider this event.  If the element is not strong enough, the sword is dropped and a new element will rise up and push forward.  Such is the pendulum of history, such is the cause of humanity.

EDIT:  To those who are saying "haven't men always done this?"  The answer is no.  As scary as that might be to you, there is no organized movement to further the cause of men.

<answer>



Yes, we do.  No, you're not alone.  We're judgmental creatures and we tend to be hardest on ourselves.  "We are living in a material world," my dear.  It's hard NOT to notice others.

The only cure I've found is to get over your outward appearance and concentrate on your attitude.  If you carry yourself tall, eyes straight-forward and embrace who you are as a person, all of the material stuff becomes less of a bother.  It won't matter what you're wearing because you will exude confidence.  It's pretty exhilarating because people will start noticing you more.

It takes plenty of practice and concentration, and you really have to feel confident about yourself.  You'll get there.  :)



</answer>

<question from>



Void/Hec...
Member since: 24 May 2007
Total points: 1674 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Why do woman get special treatment in the media?



Example: In a recent stampede in India it was reported 150 died, mostly woman & children. 45 children and 47 woman died. The article thus ignored 58 men that died.

In the "old days" woman got special treatment, but in the new age of emancipation and woman in the front line of battle, is this not a type of prejudice?



</question>



<additional details>



Yes, "battle" as in war or protests and even many violent acts



</additional details>



<answer from>



sheepyda...
Member since: 09 April 2008
Total points: 2333 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Some of the posts above are suggesting that this is what feminists want. In fact they would feel the same as you, that it is unfair to suggest that the deaths of women are more tragic than the loss of men. If we were seen equally by the media this would not happen.



</answer>

they mentioned women& children because it is the majority number. in writing articles/ essays, the majority number is always highlighted first followed by minority, and since this involved only two subjects (men + women&children) so they don't have to mention what's minority one (men). -readers can do their own math.



furthermore, children are usually mentioned with women. so women and children is one. 45 and 47 is only to show the figures difference.

Things, eh? Funny that you say that, but I don't think that people are things. My opinion of that is such that we are all different. <question from>



Eleanor B
Member since: 14 May 2008
Total points: 604 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Is selfishness a bad thing?



Richard Dawkins might disagree.

Is it even possible to be completeley unselfish, and not look out for your own interests?  And what would that society look like?  What are your thoughts on selfish people?  :-)



</question>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



It's hard to define.

For example, is protecting my child "selfish"? After all, the reason why I would protect her is because I wouldn't want to experience the emotional distress that I would experience if she were hurt or scared.

Were my parents or my spouse to become incapacitated and on breathing/feeding tubes, and it was up to me to make the choice to stop treatment, keeping them alive would probably be the selfish option (since none of them would want to live that way), but the reason I would find it hard to let go was due to love.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



I think the question on selfishness in personal human relationships in general should be replaced with a question on fairness, justice (you should give and take in equal amounts) and that selfishness should stop being viewed as one of the major vices at all times, since it is certainly a matter of degree, as many people here have already pointed out.

If our society as we know it turned to one full of altruistic people, it would certainly cease to function. Selfishness is fundamental.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



It would depend on how far it goes. If you have absolutely no regard for the feelings or well-being of others, then it's bad. If you look out for your own interests when you have to, then it's not. Even the most seemingly altruistic people are probably at least somewhat in it for the thrill of making people happy and the accolades that follow.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



It's not possible, and even if it were, it would not be healthy. Everyone has to be selfish to some degree, because if you can't take care of yourself, how can you take care of others? People (usually women) who look out only for others become run-down and bitter. The key is to find and maintain that line between selfish and narcissistic.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



You cant live your life being an island, you have to care for others around its in our nature. People being selfish are just looking after their own self because nobody else seems to care, and that could be a vicious circle.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



i h8 selfish people i really do  like giveing them a slap but sumtimes they dont no they are



</answer>

<answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



There's such a thing as looking out for yourself - not letting yourself be taken advantage of - that's not selfish in any way. Then there's total devotion to self - which is selfish.

Complete selflessness can be as bad as complete selfishness. If you are completely selfless then you are open to being taken advantage of by selfish people.



How about a happy medium between the two?



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details

</answer>

<answer>

In some cases this leads to acts we might label altruistic, and in other cases as selfish. His main thrust has always been to recognise this as biological fact so that we can overcome its worst excesses in civillised society.

People need to read Dawkins much more closely.

<answer>

<answer from>



Imposter H
Member since: 01 April 2007
Total points: 2580 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



As Gaspari said, you need to get confident.  The only way that you will be confident in your ability to talk with women is for you to do it...ALOT.  When I first started out in the game, I just came up with three very simple routines.  I would then rotate my material between conversations.  Any good routine has an Opener; "Hi my name is ____, that's a nice_____ that you're wearing."  You need a transition with a time restraint.  The time restraint is important because it allieviates her need to find a way to squirm out of the conversation.  She knows that you will be leaving in a few minutes so why bother; she might as well listen to what you have to say.  "So, what class is that book for?  English?  That's where I'm headed right now, I don't imagine we have the same professor do we?  Last week in class we were reading the most boring book...(go on to converse about your shared experience reading something you hate or what book you loved)  Finally, "I'm going to be late for class, do you drink coffee?"  "I think you should buy me a cup of coffee after class."  "No?"  "Alright, I'll buy you a cup."  "Well, do you want me to use smoke signals to let you know when I get out of class or are you going to give me your phone number?"  This is just a very simple example of a routine.  If you already know basically what you are going to say, it will help you deliver it with confidence.  Use your small set of routines over and over until you are really good at them.  After you master these routines, create more.  Create ones which are specialized for certain types of women.  I have been gaming for about 6 years and I have over 100 routines. Some are very specialized and some are borrowed from people more talented than myself.  Just get out there and do it or sit around and regret not doing it.



</answer>



<answer from>



Artie
Member since: 16 June 2008
Total points: 6730 (Level 5)

<answer>



I was very slow (out of the gates) I made up a questionnaire and asked girls fifteen questions including where they came from do they party. if invited to a frat party would they come and if they came would they bring extra girls if admission was waved&gt; what their favorite sport was is they surfed, or liked to dance. how old they were and their phone number and you know what I thought was not much to offer I asked five girls a day for a week and then went back to find them and talk again to them (on the questionnaire I wrote notes like what she looked like and hair style and where on campus and what day and time I met and did the questionnaire with her) that way on the same day around the same time I had a better chance of seeing her again and it worked I became confident and started dating a few really nice girls I met that way.



</answer>

When female friends of mine were on active duty in Iraq, they were required to wear a head scarf if they were leaving the base.  Is it sexist? Yes. The men did not have to.  Was it protecting them from extremists with guns. YES!!

<answer from>



RAZNA
Member since: 26 August 2008
Total points: 1181 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



It all depends on where they live and what the weather is!  I live in Texas where the temperature rises above 100 degrees Fahrenheit (above 20 degrees Celsius) in the summer.  If you wore woollen anything in that kind of weather, you'd just keel over and die!  We tend to wear as little as possible, let me tell me you!  Short shorts, sleeveless blouses, nothing on the head (although I do wear a hat to keep the sun off the face -- avoiding future skin cancer, you see, but most palefaces want a tan).  And if they live in small towns, they nod the head and say "Howdy" here.  In California, if you say "howdy," people think there's something wrong with you!  In big cities, people do something that sociologists call "Civil Inattention."  That means, when you get close enough to speak, you let your eyes glaze over, you glance away from the person's face or you look at the ground or the sky -- anything so you don't meet their gaze, which is rather like a threat (kind of like with gorillas, you see).  And you mustn't speak or you will thought a panhandler, begging for spare change.  Rather sad, isn't it?
Since I live in a medium-size city, I never know which to do!  So I keep glancing from the sky to the person to the ground to the person ... until we're past.  I keep hoping the person will speak first, so I can go ahead and speak.  But I don't dare make the first move.  What a coward!



Source(s):



Master's degree in sociology, minor in anthropology, moved from California to Texas to Great Britain, to Nebraska, back to Texas!  Now teaching English as a second language for 5+ years



</answer>



<answer from>



Jackie
Member since: 11 July 2007
Total points: 1252 (Level 3)

<answer>



It's only your opinion that we "say so little" - you may just not be listening to everything.  But, you're entitled to your opinion, so I won't argue the point.  However, you asked why, so here's some insight.
I personally talk a lot because I just enjoy talking, simple as that.  I also enjoy listening - I just enjoy conversation in general.
The problem may be that you're just spending time around the wrong women.  I won't deny that there are some yappy chicks out there who just drone on about nothing.  Avoid those and find women who are intelligent, educated, and have something meaningful to say.  But bear in mind that those women may still like to talk a lot.
For the most part, it's ingrained in us.  For centuries, women have been in villages together - raising children, preparing food, and taking care of the home.  Everyone had to communicate and work together to get things done, so that meant a lot of talking... to the children... to the other women... The men would be out hunting, which means they needed to be quiet, even when hunting in a group.  Talking had to be very limited - in other words, whatever they had to say, it better da*n well be important.
Ultimately, you're probably just not interested in what they're talking about.  Men can go on and on and on about nothing too.  But to them, it's not nothing.  If a group of women are together and a group of men are together (like in a bar or restaurant), neither group will usually talk more or less than the other group.  They're all finally among people who like to talk about the same things, so they do.  It's all relative.

Edit: Big surprise - a thumbs down.  Oops... looks like I talked too much.  God forbid I use more than one sentence to answer.  For all the guys who don't want to listen to women, that's fine - just don't spend time with them.  I don't like NASCAR, therefore I don't watch it.  It's an EXTRAORDINARILY SIMPLE concept.



</answer>



<answer from>

<answer>



--Retail (that is, if you were white and spoke crystal clear English.) 
--Factory work/seamstress. 
--Typist.
--Grade school teacher (er, actually, high schools weren't created until the early 20's so maybe it's better if I say ANY school teacher.) 
--Nanny/Household sevant
--Prostitute (if you were down on your luck.) 
--Nurse/Midwife
--Boarders

Those are all that I can remember off the top of my head at the moment, but women have been in the workforce since the beginning of the Industrial Revolution.

<answer from>



Joan S
Member since: 01 June 2007
Total points: 1224 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



The lower classes would do rough domestic/farm work, taking their babies with them.  Or, as the Industrial Revolution swept the country, they slaved in factories.

Single working class women (from the age of 11 upward) would be put into service in the houses of the wealthy.

Educated women (able to read, write, sew, knit) might teach in schools or work as governesses.



Source(s):



The books of Charles Dickens, Thomas Hardy, Elizabeth Gaskell, Flora Thompson, etc.



</answer>



<answer from>



Musica
Member since: 05 July 2006
Total points: 21550 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Other - Society & Culture



</answer from>



<answer>



Apart from "the world's oldest profession?"  (which was very widespread in that era despite all their so-called high morals.)

Women in the Victorian era were primarily

homemakers but they also helped to run the farms

domestic service such as maids, governesses, nursemaids, laundresses

in urban areas, some worked in factories or were seamstresses

However, as women began to go further West, the job opportunities opened up considerably more. Some of those women were...

teachers (especially in the old West where they were called "schoomarms")

nurses (and in a few cases Doctors!)

cooks
entrepreneurs/shopkeepers 
artists (like Mary Cassatt) and writers (including reporters like Nelly Bly)
actresses and singers 
hoteliers/barkeeps
homesteaders
prospectors in gold mines
stagecoach riders (such as Stagecoach Mary Fields of Montana)

Some Victorian women were even spies, professional gamblers, and outlaws!



</answer>



<answer from>



Julie
Member since: 08 November 2007
Total points: 161 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



The term Victorian covers a broad spectrum, as it covered a broad time frame-approximately 60-70 years.

Most of the upper class and middle class probably wouldn't have had jobs outside of the home, and if they did it probably was only to help tend a family business, etc.
If a woman did have to earn a living there were several options.  She could become employed as a seamstress, which payed little (unless she was lucky enough to be a dressmaker for some of the upper class).  She could do handwork to sell (embroidery, etc.)  Many women were governesses, maids, etc.  Factory work was also a possibility.  If a woman was educated, she could find employment as a teacher (or governess as stated before).  Even if she could not find work outside of the home, she could take in ironing, sewing, or washing for a busy middle class lady (upperclass women would have had a live-in maid).
Nursing and clerking (secretary) were even possibilities.
Of course, some were reduced to prostitution and begging, but those were not by any means the only options.



</answer>



<answer from>



Louise C
Member since: 09 January 2008
Total points: 41910 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



History



Books & Authors



Gender & Women's Studies



</answer from>



<answer>



throughout the Victorian era, domestic service was probably the largest area of employment for working-class women.  Large numbers also worked in factories, or in sweatshops (i.e sewing clothes).  Laundry work was another way a lot of women earned a living. For middle class women, teaching was the main acceptable way to earn a living in the early part of the Victorian era, though quite a lot of women earned a living through writing.  There were many succesful women authors in the Victorian period.



From the 1850s onwards, nursing became a respectable occupation for women, due to the reforms made by Florence Nightingale to the nursing profession.  Schools of nursing were opened in England, and nursing also became a highly esteemed occupation in the USA.  A great many women worked as nurses during the civil war, about four thousand professional nurses and many more as volunteers.

Elizabeth Blackwell became the first woman to graduate from a USA medical school in 1850, and other women entered the medical profession in the course of the century.

Quite a lot of women began to be employed in government jobs during the Civil War, and continued to work in government posts during the later part of the Victorian era.  By 1900, a third of all government jobs in the USA were done by women.  A great many women were employed in offices, the invention of the typewriter in 1868 greatly increased employment opportunities for women in office work, by 1900 three quarters of all the USA's typists and stenographers were women.  Women were also hired as telephone switchboard operators.

A lot of women worked as sales clerks in the new department stores, by 1900 142,000 had been hired.  The work was hard but not necessarily grim.  An in-house newspaper written by the workers at the Seigel-Cooper department store was crammed with stories about who was dating and whom and comments on other workers' hairstyles, and clothing, dancing ability, and general popularity.



Library work was another area where many women were employed , they were praised at the 1876 American Library Association meeting for being "the best of listeners".

Some women went into journalism, the reporter Nellie Bly became famous in the 1880s for her 'stunt' journalism, she got herself committed to an insane asylum, posed as a homeless woman, and inserted herself into the New York deomimonde as a way of exposing conditions in the city's jails and hospitals.



In 1888, she became an international celebrity when she announced that she intended to become the first person to go around the world in eighty days.  She managed to make the trip in seventy-eight days.

Women who went out west found that they could make a lot of money in catering.  There was a shortage of good cooks, and a woman called Luzena Wilson who started cooking for miners in a mining town near Sacramento, she made $20,000 dollars in six months, which she invested in a hotel and store.  A woman wrote from California that she had made $11,000 in less than a year baking bread and cakes "in one little iron skillet".  With only a few dollars, a woman could open a makeshift boardinghouse and earn a comfortable income.



The labor shortage in the early West wiped out the normal rules about what jobs were appropriate for women.  They worked as barbers and advertised their services as doctors, lawyers, and real estate agents.  Nellie Pooler Chapman took over her husband's dental practice in Nevada City, California.  "A smart woman can do very well in this country" wrote young woman to a friend back east.  "It is the only country I was ever in where woman received anything like a just compensation for work."

Re: the comment above that says that women have been in the workforce since "the industrial revolution".  women have actually been in the workforce as long as there has been work.  There has never been a time in history when women have not worked.



Source(s):



'America's women: 400 Years of Dolls, Drudges, Helpmates and Heroines' by Gail Collins



</answer>



<answer from>



Jo
Member since: 30 April 2008
