Eleanor B
Member since: 14 May 2008
Total points: 937 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Patriarchy is a theory comparable to that of institutional racism - ie, it is not that individuals are attempting to be racist, but that the system / society acts against people of a certain race, inadvertently.  For example, let's say there was a law that circumcised men could not become doctors, this would affect some races more than others.

Likewise, patriarchy is the theory that institutional systems act, often inadvertently, against women.  So before we had pregnancy and maternity leave, a woman would have to take time off sick to have a child, and too much time off sick would lead to her being sacked.



I do not concern myself too much with patriarchy, as I believe in personal, rather than social explanations / solutions to problems.  However, that is not to say that it does not exist - and as for evidence for the Illuminati, just how gullible are you?!  :-)

Edit - interestingly, many men actually make reference to a similar oppression faced by men.  For example, that the legal, health and education systems favour women.  Are they also falling foul of 'conspiracy' theories, or do they have a point?  You're free to decide either way, but you need to realise that these theories of systematic oppression are not just confined to feminism.  And as for the Illuminati, it's okay, lots of blokes believe in it.  And Star Trek.  Women understand this, and we love you anyway  :-)

Edit - I don't think you understand what patriarchy is.  No-one is suggesting a particular group of men got together and decided to oppress women, therefore I cannot show you such a group.  I cannot show you the men who decided to keep women oppressed, but I can show you many women who live in poverty due to having an insufficient pension in old age.  It is not that the system decides to be sexist, but that the system works against particular groups for various reasons.  So any stats which show current systems have a worse effect on women ARE evidence of the patriarchy, and if you are waiting for names and evidence of secret meetings, you will be waiting a long time  :-)



</answer>

Karen S

<answer>



Just read your post - what are you talking about?!

All people, male or female, of any age, of any religion has legislative protection from forced marriage.  It is, in fact, illegal to force any individual into marriage within the United Kingdom - I refer you to the Forced Marriage (Civil Protection) Act 2007.

That is not to say forced marriage never occurs, but it most certainly is illegal.  If criticism lies anywhere, it is at the door of ignorant people who claim and perpetuate the lie of no legislative protection.

There are also many other laws that can come into play when dealing with forced marriage - those involving kidnap, domestic abuse, assault and so forth.  I also refer you to the Family Law Act 1996.

Of course, for any legislation to be effective, it needs enforcement.  This, in part, requires the cooperation of the individual involved - understandably, this is frequently difficult. They may need to leave their families, even prosecute their families - an incredible emotional and traumatic experience for all involved.  Support agencies and the Forced Marriage Unit also need to be openly available for assistance - an area which is, no doubt, under resourced.

More recently, proposals have been made, and subsequently declined, to make amendments to the current legislation.  It was deemed, in consultation with community, asian, women and family protection groups, that current legislation was adequate - that harsher laws would lead to criminalising families and become reliant on sole individuals prosecuting their parents.  It was agreed that harsher laws would only serve to isolate victims further.

The best thing to emerge from these recent consultations is the need for greater awareness within 'at risk' communities and better training for professionals who work in arenas where forced marriage may be an issue.

I hope this has provided some enlightenment of forced marriage issues.



</answer>



<answer from>



louisebr...
Member since: 05 August 2006
Total points: 1999 (Level 3)



</answer from>

They ask if I was spanked as a child (mildly) or if I was ever sexually abused (never), but I have spoken to dozens of women who are either in CDD marriages or want to be in one, and there is no common denominator that I can find.  Through many studies, I have come to the conclusion that it is simply in me and many other women to need to feel their husband's authority in a tangible way.  But we also have a great need to feel like he loves us through it all.  I believe one of a woman's greatest needs is to be cherished.  It sounds like you are getting that feeling of authority, but you are not feeling cherished after it is all over.



</answer>

<answer>



Perhaps on some level, are you confusing fantasy with reality?  I'm one who likes to be abused in the bedroom.  My partner calls me **** and many other dirty names.  He pulls my hair, spanks and bites me, sometimes leaving bruises.  But this is all with my consent.  Actually, he wouldn't do any of that except for the fact that I enjoy it.  But this is fantasy.  If I was honestly being called a **** or abused in real life, I wouldn't stand for it.

I think you should analyze your desires to figure out why you wish for the things you do.  And you need to remind yourself, that what happens in the bedroom is fantasy only.  Even if your partner is calling you dirty names and being rough with you, it is only because you wish it.  If you didn't ask for it, he probably wouldn't want to do those things.  Talk to him.  See what he has to say about what you ask him to do to you.  If he enjoys it, ask him why.  I think having a conversation will give you deeper insight into the dynamics of your relationship, and likely give you comfort.



</answer>

<answer>



What a great answer Patois! :-)

Yes, the images at the end, when she is breaking, are extremely disturbing , when I was a little girl, I practically saw my mother like this! :-(

My father was extremely abusive, physically and psychologically. He would do cruel things, like disappearing for three days and coming back very late at night, going to my mother's room and wake her up so she could see the lipstick on his face, and tell her something like "Do you see this?....Do you?...See?..I do what I want"....my mother told me this when I was older, up to that time, she didn't understand why he had to do this to her.



Me at the age of the child in the video, saw my father breaking an umbrella on my mother's hair, fights because my father was drunk, my father punching my mother on the face...why?...why?..Because he thought she was not submissive enough...oh...no she wasn't. She was a painter, a stay at home mom and a feminist....my father tried to break her.



When my father left, it took my mother many, many years, to trust a man again, the whole poisonous relationship broke her. She used to have kind of epileptic attacks out of high stress...they could happen anywhere...and me the little girl was so afraid of them.



All this to say, that growing seeing all this, I know that, and abusive relationship between a man and woman with a child, affects that child enormously, as well as it breaks the mother when she is th abused one. The abuser moves on, or has something else on the side. Hey my father had a second family at the same time he was with us... yea, juggling two women with his children at the same time...of course this was known many years later...devastating to my mother too, when she found out! :-(

So all this personal story, to say, that in that situation, I would leave IMMEDIATELY. I know it would be difficult as you love the man, but abuse just gets worse with time, not better. And life is too short to be with someone that treats you with so lack of respect.

<answer from>



Dalli the Lama
Member since: 17 January 2007
Total points: 18311 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Most of the time it is not the religion per se, but the people and clerics. E.g. Christianity in its central doctrine says that there is no more distinction between male and female in Christ (i.e. those who are Christians), the church has been unable to implement this in practice. Even in Buddhism, among the bhikkhus (clerics) there is discrimination. We lamas do not permit any women to claim to be reincarnation of any rinpoche. To be reborn as a woman is considered second best so how can a living buddha be second best?



Just to answer a query about disciples of Jesus in the Christian religion: it would have been difficult, or even unwise, to have a mixed band of close disciples to travel with Jesus. Imagine the sleeping arrangements and how tongues would wag. But there is evidence that the 12 men were NOT the ONLY disciples of Jesus. The band of disciples went beyond the 12, although the 12 were supposed to 'witnesses', and among the Jews, the witness of men was given greater weight. By the way, the category of male and female does not apply to God.



</answer>

<answer>



Most religions teach that wives should be submissive to their husbands.  This was a universal social norm at the time that most religions were created, so it is not really surprising,

However, Christianity accords a higher status to women than most other religions do.  Paul said that in Christ there was neither man nor woman, Jew nor Greek, slave nor free, which was quite a radical concept for his day.



In the early centuries of Christianity, women were among the most eager converts, and were frequently instrumental in persuading their husbands to convert, as happened with Queen Bertha of Kent for example, and Queen Clotilede of the Franks, who persuaded her husband Clovis to convert.



</answer>

<question>

<answer>



Ethically and depending on the profession (e.g. modeling, acting, etc.), yeah, it would represent a conflict, but there would have to be a basis for the HR department to suggest this on objective grounds.  This may or may not be difficult for them to show.  If her CV is significantly lacking, then you may have trouble, but if her CV isn't terribly different, they'd have a tough time proving this.



</answer>

<question>



Are first-wave feminist Suffragists rolling over in their graves at what modern feminism has become?



Most anti-feminist equalists like myself agree with the original tenets of feminism brought on by the first wave -- equal rights & opportunity for both men & women.

Today, modern feminism has been corrupted by radicalist misandry. Modern feminists have perversed feminism in the same way that Muslim extremists have perversed Islam.

Would the original feminists side with the tenets of modern feminists; male-bashing, anti-male discrimination, preferential treatment & privilege for women, female chauvinism, sexism, and female supremacy?



</question>



<additional details>



louisebro2000: You find a typo in my posting, and claim that an "entire" gender is responsible for my typo? LOL!

Why are the top linguists, authors, poets, orators, and speech-writers male, if we're so horrible at the English language?



</additional details>



<answer from>



R. Gaspari
Member since: 10 July 2008
Total points: 3858 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Gender & Women's Studies



Medicine



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



The original Feminists (women's rights advocates) simply wanted fairness.  They never wished for supremacy or revenge.  If they could see what modern Feminism has corrupted their righteous cause into they'd roll over quite a bit in their graves.

This modern Feminism is all about supremacy by any means.



</answer>



<asker's comment>

</asker's comment>

<original file>index;_ylt=AtGdNCjcvmn3flMR0Q2fQNCACAx0d5f.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk48046.txt</current file name>



<category>



Social Science



Gender & Women's Studies



</category>



<question from>



Dexter G
Member since: 17 November 2007
Total points: 175 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Why should your employer pay for your babies?



Time off unpaid, I can accept. (even if your colleagues might be annoyed at all the extra work they have to do).

But for your employer to be forced to pay you to take time off to have your babies, when it has absolutely no benefit to them whatsoever... why? At a time when the world is ridiculously overpopulated?

Why do modern women want everything, but seem unwilling to make any personal sacrifices at all?



</question>



<additional details>



J: women get paid sick leave too, last time I checked. I'm talking about something which is a choice, and which is something extra to what men get.



Woody: are you an employer?



Feminism isn't about just having their cake and eating it (what's the point of a cake if you don't eat it?) It's about having other people's cakes and eating them too.

We as a society, for example, when we transitioned from horse and buggies to automobiles, decided as a society of taxpayers to support working men and end the practice of toll roads.  We built elaborate highway systems and bridges to gease the skids of commerce that led to prosperity as we grew and evolved within a more complex technological society.  And we choose nobly and wisely to spread the cost of that over the ALL of us.



The Industrial Revolution changed our entire culture and economy and women had to enter the workforce en masse to help support their families long before "hairy-legged feminists".  We as a society need to face that reality honestly, do right by our children and figure out how best to take care of the children of working parents and spread the cost of that over the ALL of us.  Developed nations with large numbers of women entering the workforce began doing that over 30-40 years ago and now enjoy a far higher standard of living than the U.S. today, lower crime rates and social welfare costs, and their children enjoy the highest academic scores in the world.

Working women should strike, go home, draw a welfare check and let martial law take over as society falls apart until we have what we NEED, quality childcare, universal health care for children, better schools for our children, a better family-friendly economy and work conditions including paternity/maternity leave and respect for workers who have children.  Where do people get off thinking that working parents and children don't have rights in a society?

<answer>



I have to say I agree. Being pregnant myself, I know paid parental leave would be very nice, and it is something that employers should at least consider, especially if they have a really good employee who's worked for them really hard for a long time, but I think whether or not to offer it should definitely be the decision of the employer, not the law. The fact is, my employer did not make me pregnant. That's something I chose to do, and whether or not I could afford the financial burdens that go along with that, including taking time off work, is something I should've been, and was, thinking about before I made my baby in the first place. I'm not trying to be judgmental of anyone. I realize things happen in life that people don't expect or plan for, but that's not just the case with having kids, that goes for most anything. If you bought a new motorcycle on credit and had an accident, receiving a broken leg that kept you from working for awhile, well that situation sucks for you: you're not going to be able to have some income for awhile and you're gonna have new expenses, but what does that have to do with your employer? Should he be expected to pay you for a time in which you won't be useful to him? You have every right to take time off to recover and have your job secure when you're better, and you have a right to dip into whatever benefits you have available as far as sick hours, vacation hours, etc,. but is it unreasonable to expect you to do that? After all, that's what you have those benefits for, and if you don't have those benefits, that's unfortunate too, but once again, how much can you really expect your job to take care of you in your personal life? I don't see pregnancy and maternity leave as any different than any other circumstance that would take you away from work for awhile. People need to realize there is no benefit without some kind of sacrifice. If employers had to offer paid parental leave, it would cost companies outrageous amounts of money, requiring them to compensate for these costs in various ways, because not only would they have to pay the workers taking off, but also their replacements, which would quickly mount up, especially for big companies with many employees, amounting to thousands of dollars a year. That would have to be made up some way, possibly requiring cuts in employee pay and benefits, not to mention, the cost of goods and services would go way up. So in the end, do even the ones that expect to benefit from paid leave really do just that? The money has to come from somewhere, and if not from the employer or other employees, then where? The government? Should it be tax payers' responsibility to provide for other people's families? I believe that's called welfare. My husband and I have worked hard to have the life we now have and we see it as our responsibility to take care of the child we've made together. It's no one else's responsibility to take care of us and it's not our responsibility to take care of anyone else. I realize people make mistakes and shouldn't have to pay for them for life but other people shouldn't have to pay for it either, be it families, friends, employers, coworkers, or taxpayers. I'm not trying to sound preachy or holier than thou, but I am not nor have I ever been close to wealthy and I've never relied on anybody to help fix a mess I've made. I deliberately did everything I could to delay having kids until I had researched the financial and emotional burdens of it and made certain I had the ability to shoulder such burdens and I feel strongly that others should feel obligated to do the same thing.



</answer>

Karen S

<answer>



After reading your question, it appears you are only asking it based on two huge, inaccurate assumptions on your part.  The first, is that employers pay Maternity (not for babies as you suggested, but in fact, for 'leave' due to pregnancy).  The second inaccurate assumption is that it has no benefit to an organisation.

So, to deal with your first inaccuracy - Maternity Leave.  Although a woman may indeed receive her maternity pay, on her usual payslip, with the usual deductions from her employer, this money is recovered by that company from the government.  Larger companies, do indeed, pay some maternity - but 92% is recovered from government via NI/PAYE.  Small companies are in no worse position (despite the old argument that it is unfair or difficult for small companies to employ women of child bearing age).  Small companies, those whose National Insurance contributions are under 45,000, are reimbursed 100% of the Statutory Maternity Pay PLUS an extra 4.5% 'compensation'!



So it is, in fact, the Government and Society, who pick up the 'perceived burden' of Maternity Pay.  This is because intelligent, sensible society recognise the need to have children and create the next generation, and of course, the biological constraints that only women can bear those children.  (Yes, overpopulation is a global issue, within the UK in fact, not enough children are being born and the problems that this will cause for future generations is an entirely separate discussion - but suffice to say, when you're old and infirm, someone will need to wipe your backside and empty the commode for you!).

As to benefits for the company of paying Maternity, as aforementioned, there are fewer financial difficulties incurred than most people believe and ignorantly bandy about without any real understanding (sound familiar!).  Any costs that do arise are certainly far less than those arising from a crashed computer system or annual management jolly to a luxury hotel dressed-up as 'Training and Development'!

If a women has applied and been successful in attaining a job position, then she must possess the right attributes for that post.  During her employment she will have developed experience, maybe a rapport with clientele or multidisciplinary department relations etc.  In essence, an integral part of the working team.  No company wants to see this go, or find a replacement and start from scratch with another employee.  Have you ever heard discussions about problems with Staff Retention or Staff Turnover?  High levels cause organisations a huge headache, where and when possible, all companies try to 'retain' there staff.  This is why it's important for companies to pay maternity, to 'retain' their employees - and attract others too.  So much so, that the vast majority of larger organisations and public services not only provide the Statutory Maternity Rights and Pay as laid out by legislation, they go the extra mile and include what is termed as 'Enhanced Maternity Benefits'.  They pay their employees above the Statutory Maternity Pay, provide bonuses for returning to work, financial assistance with childcare and 'phased return to work' flexibility.  If employing women, and/or employing women of childbearing age, was unprofitable and cost ineffective, then companies would certainly not do this would they?

Whether, man or woman, it is in the best interest of any organisation to value their employees - maternity is just one of the ways in doing so - just like providing 'paternity' leave for fathers.

I hope this has been enlightening and helped adjust your somewhat ignorant ideas.  Although sometimes I find ignorance is often an excuse for run-of-the-mill stupidity - and I guess, there is no helping with that.

Karen



Source(s):



</answer>



<answer from>

<answer>



You're clearly not educated in management are you? There are a lot of benefits employers give both male and female employees that may not seem on the surface to directly contribute to the business but it does.



Human resources has become a competitive field and may jobs come with perks to attract talent and loyal employees. Parental leave is just many of those. Some include extended health benefits, personal leave and flex hours.

Coworkers do not usually have to deal with extra work when a person takes a parental leave. Usually a temp is hired. There is some disruption in work when this happens, but as all work places deal with parent and other types of leaves, no one is really at a greater disadvantage than another because of this.

Modern women make quite a lot of sacrifices. As it takes two people to make a baby and usually men also want families, some one has to take time off work to raise a young child. Usually it is the women who does this, losing work experience, promotion opportunity and social connections. More and more men these days are taking up that responsibility, but asking for a maternity leave is hardly shirkingresponsibilitiess. Until you have done it yourself, I don't think you are qualified to make judgement on those who have.

<answer>



First, said person would need to prove that there is a "Right to own slaves", and in trying they would run into so many contradictions that there would be no consistency in the persons moral philosophy.

People today like to make up "rights" and say that they are entitled to them. Right to health care, right to education, right to a job. What they don't realize is that by creating new rights without any account for consistent moral philosophy they create irreconcilable contradictions. They advocate an unpractical moral ideal. How can you support property rights if you support the right to health care and education? You MUST violate property rights to uphold the newly created rights. SO if you believe in any of those sorts of things, say "bye bye" to your property rights. Ill be taking your computer, thank you!



</answer>



<answer from>



Scouse
Member since: 29 July 2006
Total points: 23231 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



The two are not mutually exclusive but are difficult ot reconcile.  I think here of The society of Friends (Quakers) who were large in the sugar trade which depended on slave labour.  Given the slavery laws in UK (I can only speak of UK and England in particular)  the right to own slaves died out with the last slave. Therefore in UK the answer is redundant.



We then come to criminals forced to work. these people can be said to live in near slavery but are paying a penalty and  do receive some  payment for their labour and are not usually in prison and forced to work for a great length of time and there is also a  voluntary element in that work. They are not owned by the State but are restrained by it .



</answer>

<answer>



Women walk around with a sense of entitlement, as if the world owes them something.



These kind of women don't like me, because I believe these women don't deserve any more than any man. It should be equal.

EDIT: I think these women, like the one below me, have missed the entire premise of your question. You're asking, why should everything given to women simply because they ask for it, despite it having negative effects on society or other groups?

Example: If crackheads get together and want crack to be legalized to help out their cause, should we just give it to them? What effect would it have on the rest of society? We can't just give groups things without analyzing the possible/plausible ramifications it will have. Yeah, I know that was an extreme example but it was just an example to make a point as clear as possible.



</answer>

bluegoat...
Member since: 14 April 2008
Total points: 30926 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Psychology



Higher Education (University +)



</answer from>



<answer>



http://www.sba.gov/services/contract...i...



http://www.sba.gov/idc/groups/public...d...



The US Small Business Administration (SBA) defines a small business according to its average annual receipts or the number of its employees. Here are examples from the SBAs Table of Small Business Size Standards setting forth the maximum average annual receipts by industry that a business can have and still be classified as a small business:



Crop production of all types  $750,000
Animal production except for cattle & chicken/eggs  $750,000
Cattle feedlots  $2.5M
Chicken/egg production  $12.5M
Forestry & logging  $7M
Fishing  $4M
Irrigation, sewage, water supplies  $7M
Housing construction  $33.5M
Heavy and civil engineering construction  $33.5M
Dredging and cleanup  $20M
Concrete, framing, and other housing contractors  $14M
Car dealers  $23-29M
RV, motorcycle, & boat dealers  $7M
Furniture, hardware, clothing & sporting good stores  $7M
Electronic stores  $9M
Supermarkets, gas stations & department stores  $27M
Pharmacies  $7M



There are many more examples at the link. In addition, most of the industries in the Table  such as manufacturers of food, beverages, apparel, print, oil/gas, plastics, plumbing, machinery, computers, electronics, electrical, transportation, and furniture  are considered small businesses based on their total number of employees instead of average annual receipts. In those industries, the cut-off between small and large businesses ranges from 500-1,000 employees per business/industry.



Its difficult to imagine a business that has 50 or more employees (let alone 500-1,000) that has receipts of less than $250,000 per year. And, given the SBA definitions of small business, it seems likely that many small businesses in a wide range of industries have receipts of more than $250,000 per year.



If so, it is appalling that Obama would imply that, if he is President, a small percentage of businesses exceed the $250,000 per year cut-off for increased taxation under his tax plan. In fact, the number of businesses subject to additional tax is large and is over the 50% number John McCain mentioned.



98% of all businesses in the US are classifed as small business.  Hence, many will simply close their doors (we are already seeing that), and others leave.  (former executive SBA/Washington)



</answer>

Member since: 02 October 2007

<answer>



Yes & No.



For the individual woman since they can make their own choice my opinion is irrelevant. I may approve in some cases but not others.



But in general there is a problem. Take shaving for instance (very minor surgery but still body alteration) there was a time when women had a choice in the matter. Nowadays this form of surgery is considered the norm and women are 'expected' to do it. This is the reasons why i have a problem with it. The issue is more one against the media and society. The prevalence of cosmetic surgery causes the bar to be raised for all women this leads to more pressure on women to get it done. Thus creating conformity rather than individuality.



So as i said for a woman I don't have an opinion but regarding women in general I am against cosmetic surgery.



_()_



</answer>

This isn't a "scientific" answer or a "feminist" answer but here you go:



I think its better to buy in bulk, which is what Sam's Club is for. <answer>



A guy (were talking about stereotypically) sees what he needs, goes in and gets it and gets out. One track mind that thinks in the present and wants to get the work done in the least amount of time wasted. (Im terrible sorry if I offended anyone who reads this).



A girl (again stereotypically) thinks about the future and thinks about many different things at once, so she goes in and notices a sale and thinks about the future and says hm-mm, if I buy that now I can save money, since I know I will need it later. So they see another item on sale and buy that too. This process continues until she is sure she has everything she needs.



Some instances they start thinking about things they meant to get later that week and would save time and energy later.  For example a girl will go to a place like Walmart to get shampoo and conditioner. Then they start thinking that they needed a gift for a friend whose birthday is next week. So they buy a photo album for the gift. Then they remember that they needed new sheets since the old ones now have a huge hole in it. So they buy a new set of sheets (and of course its not just the ripped sheet they need to replace but the whole bed set; because everything has to match after all (still being stereotypical). This process continues until she can no longer think of anything she needs or the whole store has been scavenged through.



On a note Im am again very sorry if I offended anyone. Just remeber this is sterotypical and not everyone is like this. Some research does show that girls think about many things at once and that their mind is constantly in motion. They think about things that need to get done, things that have gotten done, and things that are currently being done (grocrey shopping: comparing prices and thinking about what food at home that is running low). Whereas a guys mind is usually more focused and directed, thinking about what he is doing in the moment or what he will be doing that night. There are known instances where these ideas prove false, not all girls think a particular way and neither do guys.



</answer>

In Australian immigration policy a distinction is regularly made between women and children (often treated erroneously as equivalent to "family groups") and single men. The details are subject to current debate and recently failed legislation (August 2006) in the Australian Parliament. But for example in one recent case, the Minister for Immigration, Senator Amanda Vanstone, determined as follows concerning Papuan asylum seekers: "The single men on the boat would be sent to an immigration detention centre, but families would not be split up and would be housed in facilities in the community".[12] The discriminatory treatment of single women (routinely assumed to be members of some family) and single men evident in such a practice is rarely examined in the Australian media

<question from>



Proud Stepford Wife
Member since: 04 June 2008

</question from>



<question>



Why do people think that teens don't have self-control?



There are a lot of people who say that teens will have sex no matter what because of their raging hormones and if they aren't taught about "protection"(if you can even call it that) then they will not know how to prevent pregnancy. Not true. I was only taught abstinence, but I wasn't retarded. I knew what birth control was and how to get it and I knew about condoms without my parents or teachers telling me.



Is there honestly no trust in todays teens to make mature decisions anymore?



</question>



<answer from>



Colonel Reb
Member since: 28 November 2007
Total points: 15562 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I don't know.  People also think all teens will go off and drag race at 100 mph, or smoke anything that can be inhaled, or get drunk every Saturday night.  Or maybe that was just my parents.  I never did any of those things.  I didn't always do the smart thing, but I never did anything like this.  My problems were more about what I DIDN'T do, but that's another story for another topic.  Besides, I know lots and lots of adults who make these kinds of mistakes, and often they're the same ones talking about teenagers doing these things.



On a side note, with all these people talking about how hard it is to control their hormones, I wonder why anyone questions why anyone really is surprised there are people who say rapists just can't control their urges.  A lot of these people are playing right into that argument by saying they themselves just "couldn't wait."



Marissa is right.  Sex ed is taught just about everywhere now.  It's parents who are falling down on their jobs.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks Reb:)



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Marissa C
Member since: 18 May 2007
Total points: 3788 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Anyone who says teenagers aren't aware of the different methods of birth control is full of BS. Sex ED is taught in nearly every, if not all, states in the US. With that said, we can't use that as a reason as to why the teen pregnancy rates are so high.



I don't think raging hormones are to blame either. I don't think that teenagers have any more of a sex drive than someone in their mid to late 20s.



The difference being that teens tend to feel as though bad things happen to other people, not them. As The Mrs. said, it has been proven that teenagers have poor decision making skills because that part of their brain is not fully developed yet.



So to answer your question, yes, it is difficult to trust teenagers to make mature decisions. This is why parents need to be involved so that they can help their teenagers make mature decisions.



</answer>



<answer from>



R. Gaspari
Member since: 10 July 2008
Total points: 10763 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Gender & Women's Studies



Medicine



</answer from>



<answer>



I think it's simply a matter of younger people having a certain sense of "invincibility" or perhaps insufficient judgment.  Obviously it doesn't apply to all and is probably way over-generalized, but nonetheless, as a society we tend to feel that the teens are still formative years where many still don't recognise the potential consequence of their actions.  This forms the  basis for much of our legislation and so forth.  To some extent I think it's true with respect to decision-making, but is not absolute.



I'm certainly of the opinion that if someone can hold and shoot a firearm, they certainly have the capacity to determine whether they are responsible enough to engage in coitus.



</answer>



<answer from>



Tiss
Member since: 30 March 2006
Total points: 12535 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Wait until you have teenagers, then ask that question again.  I'm not saying teens have absolutely no control, but their brains are not finished growing, and they do really stupid things - even the "good" ones.  They don't think things through like we do, and feel invincible.  With our teens,we're covering all the bases.  They know we believe they are too young for sex, and don't approve, but they also know about condoms, etc.  They know that they have no control over what a girl does with their child, should they get her pregnant, and they know they will be getting jobs, and paying for any offspring they create.



</answer>

<answer from>



Mudkip  - AM
Member since: 22 August 2007
Total points: 8938 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I wouldn't say it's because of raging hormones that teens will have sex no matter what-- it's because of raging hormones, and normal human emotions, that teens will date and have relationships no matter what.



Different relationships move at different speeds-- that much is just about individual dynamics, and is true, as far as I've seen, for adult relationships as well. A small number of teens will wait several months before kissing; others will get together through a kiss. Some will stick to kissing for months, then run the rest of the bases* in a matter of weeks; others will have only a small gap between kissing and second, but wait a very long time for the rest of it. And some--  5 percent of all people-- WILL save themselves for marriage.



I think that in many teen relationships lasting more than six months, and most teen relationships lasting over a year, the partners will start to engage in some sexual activities-- be it vaginal intercourse, oral sex, or mutual masturbation. All of these activities require protection, be it from pregnancy or sexually transmitted diseases.



So I don't think the raging hormones are an issue, but I don't think there's anything that can be done to prevent teens from having sex. Not too long ago, abstinence until marriage was a very reasonable expectation-- because people were getting married in their early and mid-teens.



As for teaching about protection-- yes, some people ARE so dumb that they don't do research on their own before having sex. Or worse-- some think that they already know everything they need to know, or have misinformation about what is and isn't safe. Many people still think "two condoms are better than one," and some even believe you can effectively avoid pregnancy by douching/jumping jacks/having sex standing up/using withdrawal (which in an adult relationship can work to some degree, but isn't plausible when it comes to teenage boys). I don't think they should be having sex without doing research, but I don't think they should be punished with an unwanted pregnancy or STD, either.



It's also one thing to know that condoms exist, but another to know how to use them. Some people don't know about squeezing the tip, or forget to check the expiration date, or are confused about that whole darned foreskin thing, or use their teeth to open it, etc etc.



Source(s):



*I'm not specifying what I mean by the 'bases' because it's different for every couple and every individual. Some couples never have oral sex at all, and in some communities it's basically expected of a couple.



EDIT: I actually agree with Gaspari for once, about the whole invincibility thing. I'm somewhat responsible, but a lot of my friends make decisions that aren't really the best for them in terms of long-term mental (and sometimes physical) health (like being in relationships where they are extremely dependent, or relying on substance abuse [and i do mean abuse, not just recreational usage] to solve their problems), or they do stupid, unimportant things that could have dire consequences (like playing 'chicken' on the highway with friends).



</answer>



<answer from>



Zeep
Member since: 02 August 2007
Total points: 18432 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Biology



Marriage & Divorce



Medicine



</answer from>



<answer>



I've got a 19 year old and 17 year old.  I think teens lack self-control in part because they remind me weekly year after year.  Psychologists study them and report that their immature brains lead to impulsive behavior, even when it's not sexual and hormonal.  An ob/gyn I chose because of her reputation as being great with young girls told me to get my daughter an injection instead of the pill at 14 because she'd never had a patient that age who actually was responsible enough to take the pill or use condoms regularly - she delivered their babies.



I'd say that "abstinence education" had a great impact on my daughter - for about a week.  Then hormones or peer pressure or 21st-century culture took over.  Both my kids were sexually active by 12 and I'm just thrilled they haven't had kids.  They and their friends all started drinking and drugging in middle school, by the hundreds, literally.



So, no, there's no trust on my part that teens will make mature decisions.  You have to mature in order to be able to make mature decisions.  A lot is the culture.  I believe every word in "Reviving Ophelia".  But a lot is the nature of being a teenager.



Source(s):



Snooping on my kids and learning way more than I wanted to know.



</answer>

<answer>



When are you going to grow up? You don't have to post a stupid question immediately after someone else does it. More mature answer for the question you are referring to by someone sensible.
.........................................
Kate is completely wrong. A uterus is a bag of skin with one purpose: it waits to nurture a baby. You can lose your uterus and be fine.



Now, if you lost your ovaries as well, that's entirely different. The ovaries are the boss. Lose them and a woman's life changes because she'd go into early menopause. You cannot lose your ovaries and keep the uterus; you can lose the uterus and keep the ovaries.



I think what you meant to ask (but couldn't because you're young yet and not very knowledgeable) is would a woman have her tubes tied for the love of her man. She couldn't get pregnant, but would still remain healthy (and non-menopausal). Many women do, but it's a major surgical procedure. Vasectomy is a minor procedure and can be reversed.



You do understand selfishness has nothing to do with it, don't you? Couples decide for themselves what works best. Most people don't practice the ridiculous, angry sexism that permeates this place.



</answer>

<answer>



Depends.  If their arguments are based on logical, factual information, then I just figure they reached a different conclusion than I did.  If their arguments are based on rumors, speculation, myth or fallacy, then I figure they're either gullible, naive, ignorant, or in denial.  I will almost always (except in the case of trolls) attempt to back up my arguments with logic and facts, even if it's just to demonstrate that my conclusion is valid, if different from their's.



</answer>

<answer>



Great Question!!!!!



I try very hard not to jump to the 'uninformed' conclusion - but it doesn't always work.  This is often the case when I am discussing or arguing with a person who has proven themselves to be massively uninformed.  You tend not to believe in their reasoning skills or their information sources.



Like the previous responder, I find the American election to be a great example of where my patience and ability to listen to others is tested - because I simply can't wrap my brain around anyone's belief that John McCain would make a great leader.  I can accept the Republican philosophy as a very good one - but certainly not in the way the party has evolved and exists at present - with its massive corruption and clinging to religion.



Do I think they aren't as bright as me?  No.  But I do wonder about how much they have investigated - objectively - the two candidates and parties.  As they TRULY exist, rather than how they have propagandized themselves.



Do I try to convince them?  No - I don't think its a matter of convincing, as much as it is the desire for a lively debate.



Scoring points?  Well that would just be nasty, wouldn't it?  Heehee...



</answer>

<answer>

If it is uninformed, incoherent and not convincing, I dismiss them as an idiot.

<answer>

More often than not, i listen more deeply, diving beneath the surface of human words that so inadequately serve.  i am always open to that spark from another which might ignite my own spark into the flame of knowing, learning, understanding beyond where i am at any given moment.



There is an alchemical combustion that takes place in the exchange of ideas and experiences...very much like the "Where two or more are gathered..." concept from the Bible.  It is this "point" of ignition that affects the  transmutation that i look for within myself.  We are all in process, and every unique process adds to another's, since we are one being fulfilling the All That Is.



Being "right" (judgment, self-interest, separation) comes from the ego and is quite out of the purview of our call to awaken from our collective sleep/ignorance.  i am here to awaken, and enfolded into that intention and purpose is the awakening of humanity as a whole, for each one is onself.  Only Source is...and we are Its manifestation.



i am Sirius



</answer>

Total points: 17277 (Level 6)

<answer>

Super Ruper

<answer>

Sirius

<answer>



i once believed in Santa Claus and the Tooth Fairy; then i believed in a knight in shining armor coming to sweep me away; then i believed in injustice in the world; then i believed that i was right about everything.  All of these (and more) have changed...radically.  Beliefs are not absolutes.  They, in fact, are based on the point to which one has developed/evolved in experience, but also what one has learned from one's experiences.  And they are constantly "changing," impermanent human constructs that come and go.



Beliefs, more often than not, are second-handed to us by others, whom we "belie(f)ve" because we see them as authorities in our lives...and over our lives, as well.  But beliefs really imply lack of knowing...one's own knowing out of one's own experiencing.



Your use of the word counterintuitive is telling, for it is the whispered intuitive guidance that steers us intelligently toward every goal.  Only this intuition can be trusted to emanate from an intelligence beyond our own limitations.  This is the "gut feeling" to which you refer...this is our inner knowing, our reliable feed from Intelligence beyond our imagining, from Source.



i am Sirius



</answer>

<question from>



Twilight
Member since: 24 September 2007
Total points: 11329 (Level 6)



</question from>



<question>



Do you ground your knowledge?



And if you do, how do you?



Short of first hand experience, we all are forced to trust information from others.  And first hand experience by its very nature is just what we happen to come across, and may not generally be true, so:



Do you ground your knowledge?



And how?



</question>



<answer from>



Man A
Member since: 31 October 2008
Total points: 126 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



That's what you looking for! Too much to type, so just watch here's the link http://www.blog-x.in/index.php?q=related...
This small video WILL REALLY HELP YOU!



</answer>



<answer from>



Super Ruper
Member since: 21 November 2006
Total points: 21086 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Knowledge is a tricky concept.  People often believe they know things, when in fact, they may not.  I am one of those people who, when asked a question, will preface my answer with "I think" if I am not 100% certain of the accuracy of my answer.



But those things that I hold under the umbrella of knowledge are grounded in the following:



1.  Assessment of the source - its trustworthiness, and if it/they have an agenda.



2.  Cross referencing with other sources - this may require actual researching, or simply testing the theory on others whose knowledge base I trust.



3.  Gut check - this isn't always the most effective, but knowledge has to sit comfortably with me.  Often, there are things that have passed the first two with flying colours, but I either choose to NOT believe it or don't want to believe it.  In either case - whether this is sensible or not - I simply ignore it.  LOL.



</answer>

<question>



Why is rape considered a crime, and abortion isnt?



First of all, with the whole feminist rights movement; feminists have tried to justify their actions in all proportions.



You might tell me that abortion takes place generally with the consent of both a husband and wife (so you cant blame only women), and in case of rape; is needed to protect a "13-year" (or whatever) old child's life from the difficulties of parenting. Have you realized what you are doing to the fetus inside her: you are KILLING it, MURDERING it. It is a crime against humanity. You might tell me women are not solely responsible for abortions, and I can also say that rape isnt committed only by men. So why all this hypocrisy from feminists?



Studies have shown that only 1 of 4 women report rape, and 1 of 10 men report rape because it will hurt their ego and damage their reputation in society. So men get raped a LOT too, they just dont tell it.



I think abortion should only be used in the case of the girl's "near-death" state. If she's about to die, she should have the right to save herself over the child. However, we have seen in the past how women have sacrificed their lives to save the child in them. Abortion is getting misused a LOT these days, over the smallest things; like a girl is not ready to start a family. If you didnt want to have a kid, you shouldnt have had sex (or sex with protection). If you wore protection, but still got pregnant; tough luck, you should have known better; now deal with it, raise a kid. Dont put your mental deficiencies on your child.



You tell me that women should have the right to do whatever they want with their bodies, the thing is: from a christian point of view, the body is not exactly yours: the body is only for the time-being; and the soul is for the hereafter. When you take a child's life; more than taking its body, you take its soul. Im sorry feminists, but you have to realize there is a LIVING child growing inside them, and taking its life is a very serious matter. Dont justify it to make women look falsely independent, you arent doing yourselves any favors.



</question>

Fort example did you know that throughout the US many hospitals have different standards protocols on how to treat men and women with the same symptoms? If an adult MALE walks into the ER(emergency room) with chest pain and shortness of breathe it is considered to be a heart attack and has to be taken in immediately to get his heart checked, but if an adult FEMALE walks into the ER with the same exact symptoms they will take her into a quiet room and have a nurse talk to her about stress management.

Emotions are wonderful, and they have their place, but they are something we need to control rather than letting them control us.

So did Locke but we're talking a long time ago and an view of women in the western culture.  Women are not "too emotional" although there certainly are some women who are. Being controlled by emotion, or being a slave to emotion, however, is another story but men can be caught up in this too.  Men have been said in the past that they are prone to "rage" or "jealously" or "possessiveness."  This can be seen quite often as Aristotle and other philosophers warn against such a state in men.  Aristotle, for example, tried to teach moderation in all things.  Yet these are also emotions, though why they are often not viewed as such is beyond me.



Men had to be taught to be rational (that was the entire point of philosophers).  Even Aristotle pointed out that if one didn't receive a certain training from a youth he would not likely ever be a wise, moderate man.  The problem was that women were not encouraged to take part in philosophy (although there were a few) and moderation was not targeted towards them.



In this day in age, however, where rational thought is valued in both genders, women have proven that they can be just as rational as their counterpart and men have proven that some of them can be just as emotional as women.  It's really not a gender thing as much as a learned thing.  And one does have to keep in mind that women are encouraged by society to express emotion while men are discouraged. <answer>

It also depends on what you want to achieve in life... <answer from>



roo2
Member since: 20 March 2006
Total points: 24385 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Drama



</answer from>



<answer>



They had very few options.  I come from a family with a lot of women like that.  My great aunts were both teachers.  They never married, and traveled the world together while on summer break.  However, they had to put up with a lot of discrimination.



My mother was born in 1932.  When she went to college, there were very few options for women.  She got her MA and went into education, but quit when she became pregnant, as that was simply what was done in the 1960s.  She became a housewife, but was obviously unhappy.  Most of the mothers in my neighborhood were unhappy.  They didn't all drink or do drugs or anything like that, but as children we all knew that they just were unhappy and frustrated.  Some took it out on their children or husbands, others just stewed.  My mom went through a dizzying number of arts and crafts in an effort to find something interesting to keep her occupied before finally giving up.



She read and studied a lot.  Looking back I can see that she suffered from mild depression.  She would never admit it, but she loved teaching and being a SAHM was a horrible experience for her.  But she really didn't have much choice in the matter.



</answer>

Argument re breast feeding - bottles, breast pumps etc.



Argument re seniority etc. - woman may be the primary provider, may have built up experience, pay rises, seniority etc.



Edit



Know It All - like I said, the woman may also have built up experience, pay rises, seniority etc. You certainly don't need to be a biologist to understand that, it's quite a simple concept. The argument that the woman should automatically be the primary care giver because the man has a greater earning potential is therefore invalid.

<question>



Can I ask you something?  What is it with women EATING and DRIVING?



Now, perhaps it's none of my business, but when I'm at a red light, I take a look around.  I see all kinds of things.  You'd be surprised how many people, both male and female, pick their noses in their car.



I see people, both male and female, getting into the music they play.  I've seen men playing with themselves.  All of this I expect, believe it or not.



But the one thing that's really getting to me of late is the sight of WOMEN EATING.  I've hardly ever seen a man eating behind the wheel (despite the fact that I know they must be eating sometimes too), but I'd say it's a 50/50 shot that I'll see a woman noshing on something.



If that's not perplexing enough, then I start wondering what exactly the deal is with the way they chew.  They look like camels, the way they chew.  And these aren't necessarily fatties.  Women across the fat spectrum seem to be perpetually stuffing their faces.



What is the deal?  Are their husbands and boyfriends starving them?  Are men actually taking the time to eat at a restaurant, while women are stuffing their pieholes on the go?

Shark

<question from>



R. Gaspari
Member since: 10 July 2008
Total points: 10806 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Gender & Women's Studies



Medicine



</question from>



<question>



Ladies, are you interested in a simple, yet interesting problem...?



Suppose you're on a game show, and you're given the choice of three doors: Behind one door is a car; behind the others, goats. You pick a door, say No. 1, and the host, who knows what's behind the doors, opens another door, say No. 3, which has a goat. He then says to you, "Do you want to pick door No. 2?" Is it to your advantage to switch your choice?



If, indeed, you opt to switch doors, then please offer a cogent argument (mathematically sound) as to why you've made this decision.



Thank you and may you have a blessed day and have only the finest quality candy in your possession in the forthcoming days.



</question>



<answer from>



doodlebu...
Member since: 24 September 2008
Total points: 784 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>

</answer>

<answer from>



green6es
Member since: 07 October 2008
Total points: 961 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I would pick number two. This is the way I thought about it. Imagine there were ten doors, and you picked say, number seven. The host opens all doors except your door and say, number nine, and gives you the choice to keep your door, or switch to number nine. Common sense would tell to change because if you do you have a ninety percent chance of winning. So in the original situation, if you stay with your door, you have a one in three chance of winning. Take door number 2, and you'll have a two out of three chance of winning.



</answer>



<answer from>



annie]
Member since: 15 June 2008
Total points: 5988 (Level 5)



</answer from>

Of course the host would ask me if I would like to switch my decision, but they always do that as a ploy of making the player confused and second-guess themselves.



Stick with the first choice you always make...



</answer>

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I disagree completely; if anything looks become less important. Now you defined your criteria as 'older age', what you did not stratify are: income and social status, her own desirability, and relationship history-(also 'self esteem').



If I answered your question plainly- 'Do women become more concerned with prospective partner's looks the older they become?' The answer would be a simple no. Why would this be the case? Older women are generally in less position to discern the qualifications of mates than are 20' somethings.-- this means that older women have less leverage in choosing a mate... however it doesn't necessarily mean that they would not PREFER more attractive looks in a man (they just don't have as much pull to be able to request this anymore).



Now it is possible that your theory holds true for financially successful women, esp. those who have been in long term relationships before (more especially with women who were long-term with marginally attractive 'nice guys' and now want to try a good looking man for size). Maybe women who are economically taken care, and are more mature no longer place as much emphasis on a man's financial stature or social status (in this case-popularity). Once again maybe theyd like to try an attractive man to see how it feels.



</answer>

GingerSn...

</answer from>



<answer>



No, it doesn't because you are using the term incorrectly.



"Visual" in *this* context means being turned on by watching porn, other people "at it", and so on.  No foreplay necessary, no stimuli of any other kind other than that which is purely visual.



It has nothing to do with what a person of the opposite sex should happen to look like to a woman.



Here is an article abstract on the subject:



"Sex differences in response to visual sexual stimuli: a review.



Full Abstract



This article reviews what is currently known about how men and women respond to the presentation of visual sexual stimuli. While the assumption that men respond more to visual sexual stimuli is generally empirically supported, previous reports of sex differences are confounded by the variable content of the stimuli presented and measurement techniques. We propose that the cognitive processing stage of responding to sexual stimuli is the first stage in which sex differences occur. The divergence between men and women is proposed to occur at this time, reflected in differences in neural activation, and contribute to previously reported sex differences in downstream peripheral physiological responses and subjective reports of sexual arousal. Additionally, this review discusses factors that may contribute to the variability in sex differences observed in response to visual sexual stimuli. Factors include participant variables, such as hormonal state and socialized sexual attitudes, as well as variables specific to the content presented in the stimuli. Based on the literature reviewed, we conclude that content characteristics may differentially produce higher levels of sexual arousal in men and women. Specifically, men appear more influenced by the sex of the actors depicted in the stimuli while women's response may differ with the context presented. Sexual motivation, perceived gender role expectations, and sexual attitudes are possible influences. These differences are of practical importance to future research on sexual arousal that aims to use experimental stimuli comparably appealing to men and women and also for general understanding of cognitive sex differences."



Source(s):



http://www.find-health-articles.com/rec_...



</answer>

<answer>



To ward off hunger during the winter months try this recipe.



Ingredients
3-3/4 cups all purpose flour



1 tsp baking powder



1/2 tsp salt



1 cup butter or margarine, softened (not melted!)



1-1/2 cups granulated sugar



2 eggs



2 tsp vanilla extract



Cooking Instructions
Sift flour, baking powder, and salt together in a medium sized bowl. Set aside.



Beat butter or margarine, sugar, eggs, and vanilla in a large bowl with electric mixer until fluffy. Gradually add flour mixture and stir with wooden spoon until thoroughly mixed. Cover dough with plastic wrap and chill in the refrigerator for two hours.



Preheat oven to 400 degrees F. On a lightly floured surface, roll out dough to 1/4 inch thick. Cut out circles with a cookie cutter or other round object, such as a glass or round plastic container. Place circles 2 apart on ungreased cookie sheet.



Bake for 6-8 minutes, checking after 6 minutes. Cookies will be done when edges are lightly browned. Do not allow cookies to get too brown. Remove from oven and allow cookies to cool on cookie sheets for 5 minutes. Remove from cookies sheets to aluminum foil on a flat surface and allow to cool completely.



What You Do



Bake your favorite sugar cookie recipe (try Amandas Sugar Cookies, above), or purchase a package from the store.



Using a butter knife, spread white frosting on top of each cookie.



Let children decorate the cookies with sprinkles, sugar, and candies.



To make holly berry cookies, place two red candies or jelly beans toward the top of the cookie and draw on leaves with green decorator gel.



For sugar stars, trees and other shapes, gently place a miniature cookie cutter on top of the cookie after its frosted. Carefully sprinkle a small amount of sugar into the cookie cutter with your fingers, being careful not to let the sugar fall outside. Gently remove cookie cutter.



You can completely cover a cookie with decorative sugar by holding the frosted cookie upside down and dipping the frosted end into the sugar to coat.



Use red decorator gel to write Ho Ho Ho! on your cookies.



A snowman can be made from candies and fruit roll ups. Cut a strip of fruit roll up, about  thick, and twist it into a rope. Place the fruit roll up around the top of the cookie as ear muffs and add jelly beans for the muffs themselves. Decorate face with colored candies.



Use cherry raisins to form the petals of a poinsettia. Place a colored candy in the center.



</answer>

<question>



Do Stay at Home Mom's have a hard time getting back into the workplace?

<answer from>



Sigy the Arctic Kitty~
Member since: 24 July 2007
Total points: 13776 (Level 6)

<answer>



Yes, it can be difficult, especially in a weak economy. How difficult it is really depends on the kind of job the returning woman is looking for and her education and skills. College is not so difficult to return to.



And it is probably more difficult for SAHDs to return to the workforce because many employers are still biased against it.



</answer>



<answer from>



Lard Tacos: The Rebirth
Member since: 16 October 2008
Total points: 942 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think it depends on the career/field. I worked full-time most of my adult life, even 2 years after I had a baby. This past year I became a stay at home mom to focus on school (and because daycare is outrageously expensive). When I go back into the workplace I will be a nurse, and I don't anticipate having too much trouble finding a job due to the demand. But if I were going back into the same field I had been in before (mental health), I definitely think it'd be difficult to find a job.



</answer>

<answer>



* Yawn* I hate when trolls aren't even funny. It takes the whole point out of trolling.



To make your house fun an lively for thanksgiving try this craft idea.
What you'll need:
1 vegetable can



Felt: brown, red, orange, tan, goldenrod, white, black



Scissors



Tail pattern



All other patterns



Scissors



White craft glue



Hot glue gun



How to make it:
Inspect the opening of the vegetable can and be sure there arent any sharp edges. If there are, use a piece of sandpaper to wear them down. Remove label, wash and dry completely.



Lay can on its side on the short end of the sheet of brown felt. Roll up to determine how much felt you will need, trim the end so that you have about an inch overlap at the top, bottom and around the perimeter as well. Glue the brown felt to the can, folding over the excess and gluing to the bottom and inside the lip of the can. Look for the seam, this will be the back of your turkey.



Using pattern, cut out the tail from a piece of cardstock, you will need this to glue your felt to as the felt is too flimsy to stand on its own. Using the other patterns, cut out a red waddle, white eyes, black pupils, brown head, black eyebrows, goldenrod beak, tan collar, and orange feet. For tail feathers, cut out 2 red, 2 tan, 1 orange, 1 goldenrod and 1 brown.



Glue the collar, straight side lines up with the top of the can, to the front of the turkey (remember, seam is in the back).



Glue the red waddle just above the bottom of the collar.



Glue the head over the top of the waddle, leaving just the bumps of the waddle showing below the head. The head will be above the lip of the can



Glue on the whites of the eyes in the center of the head. Glue on the black pupils to the white.



Glue on the goldenrod beak, overlapping the bottom of the eyes slightly.



Glue on the eyebrows above the eyes, pointing upward.



Glue 2 orange feet to the bottom portion of the can (see photo).



Lay the card stock tail template on to the table. Glue a red felt tail feather on top of the far right point. Repeat on the left side with the other red tail feather. Glue a tan feather to the next point on the right, overlapping the first red one. Do this on the left as well, using a goldenrod tail feather.



Repeat on the right with an orange feather and on the left with a tan feather. Finally, glue the brown feather to the center point, overlapping feathers on both sides. Be sure there is no card stock peeking through, all should be covered with felt feathers.



Hot glue the completed tail to the back of the can. Put some hot glue on the sides of the can and squeeze the tail feathers around the side by gripping the can with your hand.



</answer>

<answer>



For the vast majority it's purely for comfort, nothing else.  There's been no research that bras affect the Cooper's ligaments or their natural history; it's just for reasons of comfort for most.



There's no solid medical literature to remotely suggest that bras somehow pose a hazard nor do they offer a protective effect.  It's purely a matter a convenience.



</answer>

<question from>



No Picture
Member since: 09 September 2008
Total points: 348 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Why are some men whining that more women get undergrad degrees?



When SIGNIFICANTLY MORE MEN THAN WOMEN are enrolled in trade schools learning well-paid careers?



These blue-collar trade schools aren't counted in the traditional data about university enrollment because its not university:



For many, women economic incentive is primary.  Jobs that are nontraditional for women pay more than traditional female occupations



This study examined the meaning the adult women enrolled in Penn-



sylvania College of Technology gave to their life and work experiences that led them to enter nontraditional majors.



Pennsylvania College of Technology is a public institution within



central Pennsylvania offering educational programs in traditional and advanced technology.  It is an affiliate of the Pennsylvania State



University and offers associate and baccalaureate degrees with a strong emphasis on hands-on career programs. Its student body numbers 5000; 67% are male, 33% female.  Minority students comprise approximately 4% of the student population."



Women Who Opt for Nontraditional Careers (2002)
http://www.coe.iup.edu/ace/PAACE%20Journ...



</question>



<additional details>



Don't kid yourself: there is plenty of book-learning involved, in addition to the hands-on stuff.  I would want my electrician to have a "sound grounding" in what was discussed in the textbooks.



The idea is to make you "well-rounded", and so to make you educated.  I had to take linguistics and my degree had nothing to do with linguistics.  I know a nursing student who was moaning about having to take an english literature (essay writing) class.  Get over it, its good for you.



</additional details>

Member since: 07 July 2006
Total points: 20311 (Level 6)

<question from>



captaink...

<question>



Can you be a feminist and still believe in chivalry?



is it hypocritical?
are they separate issues? can anyone justify that they can co-exist?



and what do you think about chivalry in general? men and women's opinions, is it out of date? romantic? a pain in the butt?



</question>



<additional details>



gosh, i didn't realise the need to be so extremely specific
by chivalry i meant in modern day life and as there are no knights etc who ride around on horses carrying oversized poles to prod people with in my part of the world i'm going to make generalisation and apply that to every where
and by romantici meant in the idealistic sense of the word not the love sense (there's more than one meaning)



</additional details>



<answer from>



Inundated in SF
Member since: 01 November 2006
Total points: 14538 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Feminism is not about becoming a man (in the body of a woman).  It is making sure you can handle yourself, can think for yourself, can support yourself when needed, can do this life all by yourself is you need to.  You don't have to wear pant suits and combat boots and have a butch haircut (but you can if you want to).  Feminism is more a state of mind and being.  Which doesn't eliminate a certain degree of chivalry.  And a woman can act chivalrous too--hold the door for the guy coming through after you, help carry a large box by carrying one side, etc.  Nothing says a woman can't do these things.  It's kind of nice when both genders are doing the sensible thing without letting gender get in the way.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



i like the 2 way street idea



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Laughing...
Member since: 11 June 2007
Total points: 9007 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



they are totally separate issues. I believe in feminism and I see feminism as being mostly for women to get equal jobs, pay, promotions, education, housing and all economic issues just like men do.



But then I see issues about safety (walking alone in public or after dark) and reproduction as being important feminist issues where womens' needs are very different from men's.



As for opening doors etc if that is what you mean by 'chivalry' - I don't see these as what men owe to women but rather as courtesies that both sexes should extend to any person who needs some help.



</answer>



<answer from>



SJ
Member since: 31 May 2006
Total points: 2162 (Level 3)

<answer>



well you mean by chivalry that a man should treat a woman special? well, it depends, i suppose what kind of context it is used in. when a man opens the door from a woman, for example, is he operating under the assumption that the woman lacks the physical strength to do it herself so he must go in as the big man and save the little girl ? well obviously that would very sexist, very anti feminist. but if a guy opens the door to be nice, that's perfectly acceptable. although, he also ought to do it for guys if you think about it. if this extends to a man paying for the girl's dinner, i think that is against feminism as it puts the male in a position of power of the female. i guess if any action that is part of chivalry could be reciprocal, then it can fall in with feminism

tacs1ave

<answer>



Three types of chivalry,



1. intelligent chivalry, where the more suitable person assists the other person. eg: the physically stronger male might carry the ladies luggage inside.



2. consumer chivalry, where the person is effectively working for that person eg: they might have done something stupid and are making up for it by reducing her workload.



3. get in your pants chivalry, where the male is doing everything to try and make the lady feel comfortable so she will have a better time, thus increasing the chance for him of getting a home run.



</answer>

louisebr...

<answer>



No...People confuse chivalry with simply being polite and having manners.  I fervently believe that society would be a whole lot nicer if we all followed simple rules when it came to good manners, but chivalry is a male preserve that has it roots firmly in the idea that men must 'protect' women who are 'weaker' and subordinate.  It comes from a time where women were mere chattle, the property of men. Many won't agree..the thumbs will fly, but try and remember the last time you described a woman as being chivalrous, if it applies to both sexes!



We are told that it is a benign paternalism, in fact it is a reinforcer of male subjugation of women, patronising and often quite cloying when on the receiving end!
And when mentioning this in relation to chivalric medieval orders etc...those knights had a propensity to be men, and the codes were a male preserve...read Chaucer's A Knight's Tale..just to get a taste of that, but we are talking about how this notion impacts on society now.  And although I am pleased to be a woman in the 21st century as opposed to a 15th century maid..it is all still relative...knights had more fun!



Eoghan..does have some rare old ideas...lol about women...women's prisons five star hotels eh? lmao...If society incarcerates the most who threaten the safety of the public...then by that reasoning alone women's prisons would and should be virtually empty. If people are locked up just to make sure punishment is seen to be done then more and more women are going to prison.  Non payment of fines..TV licences...prostitution, shoplifting etc... crimes yes, but hardly the ones that make you wet your knicks on a night!!



Source(s):



Not believing everything I read in The Sun or The Star...lol
even the Mail or Express...and don't like the uber liberal Guardian either



</answer>

Eoghan.
Member since: 29 July 2008

<answer>
