<answer from>



shebs
Member since: 07 February 2008
Total points: 10263 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Sorry, but a pedantic response here is called for.  "Chivalry" is not about the treatment of women.  It was a mediaeval code of honour for sworn knights (and some others) and mainly regarded how he associated with his superiors and the rest of society, which was feudal.



The code of manners to which you allude is mainly based on 18th and 19th century romantic writings and re-interpretations of mediaeval society, especially in England.



Now, as regards these manners, I exhibit them because I feel it appropriate to do so.  I do not use them to recieve acclaim or appear overly romantic.  I also expect good manners in return, and the people with whom I associate are like minded.  I have been rebuked, bith by feminists and non-fems for being the way I am, but that is simply their opinion and people who stand out a little often cop it.



Should these manners be aimed at women, for their benefit alone, and should women feel entitled to special treatment?  I leave that to the individual to decide.  I tend to think that feminists who expect special treatment are being a little hypocritical, but then again, I use the manners for personal reasons anyway, so their opinion matters little.  I will not change for behaviour for an entitled princess any more than I will for a feminist who rebukes me for alleged misogyny.



EDIT:  The devil is in the detail, and as a history teacher, I guess I do get fussy about such details.  I am well aware that the only knights roaming around these days on horses are usually members of re-enactment groups.



</answer>

<answer>



I think there are many answers to this question, but there are two main things that spring to my mind.  Firstly, there is a stereotype of the militant feminists as being man-haters, and also hating women that still value relationships with men. This stereotype of a doc marten wearing, short-haired, hairy woman is often the first image that a lot of people get in their heads when they hear the word 'feminist'. Therefore in their eyes, it is not possible to be a feminist and still be feminine, and respect and appreciate men.
The second reason that comes to my mind is a lot of women will say that they think feminism is a load of rubbish, because they like the fact that men will hold doors open for them, pay for meals at restaurants for them, and actually are happy to gain their sense of security from being with a 'strong' man.  Part of the reality may be that the women that feel they need these things to feel more secure are actually somewhat envious of the more feminist types, who may be more self-reliant and happy to live independently.  I am basing my views on nothing more than personal experience, and conversations with women.  I have worked in a predominantly female environment for some time now, and although I don't claim that my colleagues are an accurate cross-section of society, I have heard their views repeated by quite a few others.  I think you really need to bear in mind that although there are many different branches of feminism, a lot of women are not fully aware of the movement and its intentions, and they only think of the militant stereotype when they hear the word 'feminism'.



</answer>

smallbiz...

<answer>



Assuming your observation is true, there are several possibilities.
--They might feel threatened in that feminists seem to suggest that women take personal financial, legal and social responsibility for themselves, when their goal was to be good wives and mothers and have husbands support them.
--They might feel that some feminists have a different sexual orientation and again feel that violates their own social mores.
--They might feel that if they embraced the feminist ideas that they would not longer be appealing to their husbands.
--They may feel feminist ideas go against their religion or culture.
--There is often fear involved with change, and it appears that the fear may be masked as anger.
Remember that feminism isn't a recent development, women campaigned for the right to vote for women, the right for women to own property, and the right for married women to sign contracts.  (A woman once told me that as a 21 year old married woman, she had to get written permission from her 20 year old husband to get a drivers license when they moved to a new state, and this was only about 40 years ago.)
It  doesn't seem possible that women who now complain about feminists would be willing to go back to the way it was 100 years ago.  Rights won in the early 20th century seemed as radical and as likely to tear apart the family then as some of their new goals do today.  Therefore, women hating feminists seems illogical.  Let's hope this is either another urban myth or a truism we can soon report as over and gone.



</answer>

<answer>



Answer hidden due to its low rating



It annoys me how the majority of answerer's talk as though there is only one type of feminist. There are at least 5. The "Germaine Greer" type. Most of the critiques against feminism by women is directed at the more controversial feminist arguments put forth by the more vocal, radical feminist who seem to get the most attention. But for the most part, if you actually take the time to read feminist theory from sources which are more academically credible then you will see that the majority of feminist theory is anything but "man hating" nor does it solely revolve around getting one over men . Most of it revolves around the idea of getting the best for women in light of the fact that women have many different social and economic standings. The biggest problem facing feminism today is that it has just been recognised that the word "woman" is a broad generalisation, there are huge differences cross-culturally between women. So feminism today is more about overcoming this, not necessarily geared towards between reconciling the two genders.



Source(s):



Professional Feminist Philosopher



</answer>

<answer from>



Kate
Member since: 19 March 2007
Total points: 5855 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Nagging is not verbal abuse.



Nagging is repeatedly asking someone to do something that is not unreasonable (ie nagging to get someone to do the dishes, nagging for sex).



Verbal abuse is repeatedly insulting someone with no cause and no concern for their well-being.



"You promised to do the dishes and I've done them for the last three days, why haven't you done the dishes?" is not verbal abuse, no matter how many times it is repeated because it is a reasonable request and isn't meant to hurt someone.



I have a very big problem with verbal abuse, but nagging is not in and of itself verbal abuse.  So your question makes no sense.  Give an example of actual verbal abuse and then you can complain about any insults you recieve.



</answer>



<answer from>



Laela (Layla)
Member since: 24 September 2007
Total points: 24977 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Verbal abuse are words that hit like a two-edged sword; the words do not draw blood that we can see.  Still, they cause pain.  They cut into the psyche; no one ever thinks that the psyche can be torn and that it can bleed, but it does.



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



A question about abortion?



How come hitting a women is a horrible crime, receiving great outcry from feminists, but aborting a fetus is acceptable?



</question>



<additional details>



I am not taking a side on the abortion issue. I am wondering why terminating the development of a fetus is acceptable, but hitting someone warrants jail time.



For some reason, I think most people would choose to be punched in the face, rather than killed.



So when does it go from "not person" to "person"?



That clump of cells has hypothetical potential. Who is to say the person being hit does not deserve it? The person being hit may be a worthless burden upon society, yet the fetus may grow up to be the next brilliant inventor. And again, I never stated I support abortion.



Previous edit ended early...what I meant to say was



I never stated that I support or oppose abortion.



Alright, I have an opinion on abortions. Terminating a life at any time is hilarious, and there are many who are worthy of an early grave. Age is irrelevant. That one person who survived the holocaust, then was shot in the VT massacre, that was death catching up to him. It took a while, but a freak occurance corrected a mistake.



I expect this to be banned. Don't dissapoint now.



Anyway, I was asking why someone striking another is a crime, even if the person may have deserved it. But aborting what may or may not be considered a life is not seen as a real issue, except when the freedom to do so is threatened.



If a man was to strike his wife when he finds out she has an affair, he will be the one who is looked down upon, though she deserved it (though some will argue that she was right to have an affair). When she goes to the clinic to dispose of the unwanted cells, she is hailed as being able to make her own choices.



Probably doesnt make sense anymore, dont care, out of text.



If someons is pregnant, chanes are the willingly engages in intercourse. They knew the risk when they did so.



What about the autonomy of the child?



And people are not free to do as they please to their person. If someone attempts to commit suicide, people will intervene, assuming they know.



So I guess laws stating I cannot take crystal meth is a violation of my autonomy over my own person.

<answer>



You don't like abortion?  Get yourself neutered so you don't make anyone pregnant.  This way you won't have to worry.



*That would depend on the laws where you live.  Where I live the Supreme Court has ruled that an embryo (most abortions occur prior to 9 weeks gestation) and a fetus are not "persons" under the law.



"Tremblay v. Daigle [1989] 2 S.C.R. 530, was a decision of the Supreme Court of Canada in which it was found that a fetus has no legal status in Canada as a person, either in Canadian common law or in Quebec civil law."



A battered woman is, by contrast, indeed a "person" as defined by law.



The End.

<question from>



unworthy...
Member since: 21 April 2006

</question from>



<question>



Why do people confuse socially defined gender roles with sexual preference?



Just because a guy likes activities that are normally prescribed as "feminine" that doesn't make him gay. And just because a girl likes traditionally "masculine" activities that doesn't make her a lesbian. It's harder to apply this concept to a female because it is more socially acceptable for a woman cross gender lines.



To take this question a step further, do you think these stereotypical labels push guys/gals to explore homosexuality when they wouldn't have otherwise? (Labeling Theory - People either embrace or reject the label placed on them by society) Do you even think it applies to this situation?



</question>



<additional details>



~nic~
I'm not talking about someone who has been told once that they are "gay"
I'm talking about the male or female who has gone all their life hearing people tell them that they are gay because of the things they like



Iridescent Leuko



Wow, very insightful! Thank you for you well thought and articulated answer!
I actually have a degree in sociology w/ a minor in psychology, so I have studied these things. I really believe that sexual preference is not innate, but sexuality is. Tabula rosa, baby! :-) I  don't think homosexuals choose to be homosexual either.  It indeed is a complicated subject.



What about the studies that show that the structure(shape/size) of the brain can actually change because of certain behaviors?



I'm also curious about people who say they've overcome homosexuality. What is your opinion on these people who go on to have happy and healthy relationships with the opposite sex?



My husband is one of those former homosexuals and he gave me a very detailed description of his transformation. Also, I have no doubt that he is attracted to me. He's not pretending!



Radium Radiator
Thanks for bringing up the asexual aspect of sexuality. It often gets ignored. :-)



Thank you all for your wonderful answers!



</additional details>



<answer from>



Iridescent Leuko
Member since: 26 February 2007
Total points: 2048 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I think I am about to think about this and muse for a moment.. or two..



Many people find it interesting and hard to believe... when they find out that most male cross-dressers are actually completely heterosexual!



We're conditioned to believe that feminine is synonymous with liking men sexually, and that masculine is synonymuos with liking women sexually.



Why, you ask?



Because of our social norms and the way we were raised..



We're raised to have certain very specific gender roles and to fall into these roles at all times.. or we could possibly be considered homosexual.



It's not even close to true -- but -- I can see where people can go wrong..



Lack of education and fear-mongering (i.e. religion, social conditioning through teasing and often physical violence against males who don't fall into proper categories, as well as SOCIAL violence against women, sometimes physical) help to create these stereotypes and help to also create fears and hatred.



I think that people that are gay sometimes are more masculine / feminine than their sexes standards.  Sometimes.  Sometimes they're a man's man who happens to be attracted to men.



Sometimes they're not, sometimes they're more feminine.  Same applies with women.



But the mere fact that a man's man could still be homosexual is what you are probably asking about.  Probably a lot of people would assume that a homosexual man would be "prissy", "weak", "feminine", "talk girly", etc. and would expect that sort of behavior out of that orientated person.  However -- this is entirely untrue...  but WHY?  Like I said before.. social norms, lack of education, stereotypes, and in some cases.. simply because it can be true.



People will also take one instance of this -- and apply it to ALL the gay people they meet.



It's like someone meeting a radical Christian and then assuming all Christians want to burn down abortion clinics.. Entirely untrue, but people somehow find a way to rationalize this.



Or racism -- someone will meet one black person in NYC and get mugged.. and then when they back to their little town, somehow make the link to ALL black people.



Or sexism.  Or homophobia.



Fear of unknown, fear of difference, social norms, conditioning..



Not everyone that believes these things we're talking about are even necessarily homophobic -- though!



My fiance, for instance, is not homophobic -- but seems to believe gay men all speak with a similar feminine tone.  He's not hateful, he just is misguided and has been indoctrinated in one of many misbeliefs that people commonly have.



It's an extremely complex thing you've asked, one that's answer could only be found if you studied sociology, psychology, and anthropology for quite a while -- and we still probably wouldn't fully understand, I know I sure don't.



------------ Second question



And, I don't think stereotypes push people to explore being gay.  I think people are born gay due to genetic and brain differences and will eventually explore this and realize it as a fact about themselves.



So.. do I think it's possible for a guy who .. say ..  loves babies and kittens, cooks, cleans, dances in the ballet, likes to wear red high heels in his spare time, enjoys manicures and pedicures, envisions himself as a "diva" or something.. Do I think it's possible -- if he's labeled "gay guy" enough.. for him to actually become gay?



That's ridiculous.



Gay can't be a self-fulfilling prophecy or applied with the label theory the way "loser" can be..



I realize people often rise or fall to expectations upon them.



Someone labeled "overly emotional" will probably come to end up being "overly emotional"..



But ... homosexuality is innate sexuality.  Innate attraction cannot be changed by words or no matter how much you push someone toward this.  It may open up someone who was already going to discover that they were homosexual -- to experiencing and experimenting to DISCOVER that they are in fact homosexual....  But it would NEVER create this in a person that it did not already exist in.



Homosexual brains, from birth, have distinct differences from their heterosexual counterparts --- in both women and men.



And female and male brains have distinct differences, too..



Look up studies about boys who are changed into girls because they were born with both sexes sexual organs or because their penises were damaged in early life..



These people pretty much NEVER conform correctly to the gender role bestowed upon them..



Because it is not their natural sex!  Someone that is male in the mind is male.



Or, people who insist they are "in the wrong body" -- these people also have distinctly different brains.  Men who believe they were born in the wrong bodies and consider themselves women often have brains more similar to that of lesbian women -- not brains more similar to men.



It's all highly interesting, and the studies I'm talking about can generally be located in



Source(s):



an anthropology, sociology, or psychology college professors arsenal ;) You may locate them at the library, in many documentaries (especially about people who have reassigned sex & gender due to a penis being malformed or damaged) and in a many textbooks, as well.



-edit- I think size/structure of certain bits can change... "use it or lose it" -- but, I think the basic set-up will never alter. That make sense?



And - I feel.. that is a mystery ;) Gay folk don't generally change sexual preference. Perhaps he was never completely gay -- but instead bi-sexual with a completely different brain from gay or straight folk. And is just denying his homosexual tendencies (beliefs CAN be strong enough to overcome instincts) and realizing his heterosexual ones?



Monks sometimes were gay and just denied the gay until they were a-sexual.. You can deny sexuality -- but it's always part of who he is.
-edit  I do not doubt your hubby is attracted to you, especially if he always had bi-sexual tendencies. Nor do I doubt the relationship is happy and healthy.  But would I say he's totally heterosexual?  In behavior, yes.  His brain is probably still inherently attracted to men (AND women, more specifically you!), though.



</answer>

<question>



Age of new gender roles ?



In the past women could not even vote and very few were being educated.Since girls and boys have equal access to all levels of education, Females have significantly higher GPA's than males in all levels of education, Since 1995 girls constantly outnumber boys in colleges,today 60 % of all college degrees were earned by women and this fourteen point gap is expected to grow more lopsided with each passing year. Girls now outnumber boys in student government, honor societies, school This gender role inversion is starting to translate in the workforce, in business and in politics,causing women to exert even more controll  within their personal relationships with men and this is happening in almost every area.



Is that gender role inversion in the world to come  ?



</question>



<answer from>

<answer from>



GingerSn...
Member since: 05 September 2008
Total points: 809 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Thing is... girls are better able to sit quietly and pay attention.  In the meantime, the boys are running around in circles.  Which students are likely to receive better grades, those who are able to sit quietly and pay attention or those ADHD cases running amok?



There is no discipline at home, or in the schools anymore.  This development has been to the detriment of the boys.



Earlier this evening I watched a documentary called "Rude: Where are our Manners?", and that's where I plucked the following quote:



"People's perception of our world is that we've become increasingly uncivil - kids are out of control, people talk on their cellphones everywhere and the f-word is a standard greeting."



This is the world we live in now, one where kids have an incredible sense of entitlement.  They fear no authority figures.  Teachers are authority figures, and teachers have lost control of their classrooms because the kids have way TOO much self-esteem.  They're not taught any manners, yet this is absolutely necessary for civil discourse. If everyone did whatever they wanted at any given time and didn't care about the people around them we would have a state of anarchy .  Boys in particular need to be controlled, and they're totally OUT of control.  This is the end result of all that "self-esteem":arrogance.  Oh yes, and low test scores for the boys who couldn't sit still, listen to the teacher, and read their textbooks.



So feminism isn't to blame for lower productivity by boys:instead,  its the amount of control the teacher has over his/her classroom that matters.  When I was in school ("before feminism") the boys were NOT running amok as they are today.  If they did, they would be punished (corporal punishment, detention).  So this experience shows that boys can learn to sit, be quiet, and listen to the teacher and their grades will reflect it.  But nowadays we just let them run amok instead.



</answer>



<answer from>



Eoghan.
Member since: 29 July 2008
Total points: 2117 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



The last thirty years has seen us change from a support/taxpayer pairing to full participation in taxation. The coming downturn may well wipe out the middle class. The old idea of a SAHM is just that. These changes are more to do with the ruling classes getting more from us that anything else. A couple does 80hrs work and has less money to spend and less leisure time than a single income couple did 40 years ago. We do twice the work for less.



So the female role has changed, before she had no choice but to be a sahm now she has no choice but to work. Will we sucessfully socialise the nesting and nurturing instinct out of women or will they be unhappy with this, will taking away the role of sahm lead to a new generation of perscription drugs?



As America reshapes itself into a communist style economy I wouldn't be in the least bit surprised if women were pegged to be the admin and management and men the grunt.



The current education system does hold boys back and there is some research being done on it. There is also a deliberate dumbing down of education and the competitive edge that boys thrive on has been removed, they get bored and lose interest.



"Sue Palmer is a former head teacher, literacy adviser and the author of 21st Century Boys. She says it is a biological necessity that boys run about, take risks, swing off things and compete with each other to develop properly. If they can't, a lot of them find it impossible to sit still, focus on a book or wield a pencil, she says, so their behaviour is considered difficult', they get into trouble and tumble into a cycle of school failure.



Boys are three times as likely as girls to need extra help with reading at primary school, and 75 per cent of children supposedly suffering from ADHD (attention deficit hyperactivity disorder) are male. We are losing boys at a rate of knots, particularly in literacy, Palmer says, because at some point in the past 30 years, masculinity became an embarrassment.



Research by Simon Baron-Cohen, a respected Cambridge professor, that began as an investigation into autism, puts a solid case for biological male/female differences in the brain, with boys tending to be systematisers and girls empathisers. This explains why boys generally are less keen on reading and comprehension, and lag behind girls in literacy. A lot of boys find it easier to explain the workings of a watch than to discuss how a character in a story is feeling. But now, says Palmer, apart from the very bright ones, boys aren't even doing better at maths and science.



Some people blame this nosedive, first noticed in the mid-Nineties, on the feminisation of education - too many women teachers, girl-friendly classroom environments and modular exam systems that suit girls' study skills but disadvantage risk-takers. Geniuses are much more likely to be male, Palmer says, but if you don't tick the right boxes, you fail.



Source(s):



http://women.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_...



http://marketoracle.co.uk/Article5810.ht...



</answer>

<question>



First wave feminism was a reaction to...?



Any feminists out there?



Thanks



</question>



<answer from>



Skibabe
Member since: 24 October 2008
Total points: 446 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Male dominated society.  Talking about Western society specifically.  Bear in mind that for centuries women hadn't just been unable to vote.  They'd been the chattels (possessions) of their husbands.  Girls were not popular as children as their father was expected to pay a dowry to get them married off - so they cost money, whereas sons brought in money (and inherited a dowry when they married).  Girls were brought up to know how to sew, sing, and that's about it.  They were there to be trophy wives, were believed to be the weaker sex (literally as well as figuratively), would never have the intelligence to cope with the things men could do, and were basically there to say very little, "lie back and think of England" instead of enjoying sex, and to bear children.  They were given a limited - if any - education, had no rights, spousal rape didn't exist because they belonged to their husbands no matter what, were not to exercise or even leave home much, and were to put up with this for life.  Any real wonder feminism emerged?



Sad thing is, in some places things haven't changed - e.g. China and India where girl babies are abandoned in favour of boys.



PS. I don't think I know what a feminist is any more?  I never used to think I was one, and I'm not militant about anything, but I'm studying Human Development at Uni, which questions what we take for granted about society.  The more I learn, the more interested I become in the place of women in Western society - but I don't hate men at all, I think they're great *lol*



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks for your answer, not only did it tell me what I wanted to know but it saddened me to think I've never really given it much thought before now. No, theres no wonder Feminism emrged.



Thanks



Terry



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



doodlebu...
Member since: 24 September 2008
Total points: 780 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



The first wave sought the right to vote, although: "women have been voting in some parts of the US since 1869 (Wyoming) i.e. years before the term feminism was even invented (in 1882 by Hubertine Auclert).



Women have voted all over the US since 1920, in New Zealand in 1893, in Finland in 1906, and in the UK 1928, but it is worth noting that many men (of colour, or non-landowners for example) were barred from voting in times past too.



I support equal opportunities for women but modern feminism has been mainly about picking fights with men rather than promoting gender equality.



Source(s):



http://www.************/feminism-evaluat...



</answer>



<answer from>



Harry R
Member since: 23 May 2008
Total points: 2833 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Which 'first wave' - the late Victorian feminism (Suffragettes) or the Germaine Greer one? The first campaigned for the women's vote. The Representation of the People Act 1918 was passed granting votes to women over 30 who owned houses. Ten years later, it was extended to women over eighteen.



</answer>



<answer from>



Tracey
Member since: 08 October 2008
Total points: 879 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



The early suffragettes fought for the right for women to vote, and it was not only a symbolic fight. Many of them were harassed, jailed, beaten, tortured and black-listed for their efforts.

<question>



Does drinking increase the risk of ALL kinds of violent crime, including but not limited to rape?



--



</question>



<additional details>



Inspired by http://ca.answers.yahoo.com/question/ind...



See: http://www.homeoffice.gov.uk/rds/pdfs2/r...



"Underage drinkers commit 45% of rapes, 44% of robberies, and 37% of other assaults"
http://www.learn-about-alcoholism.com/te...



Drinking and Violent Crime:



 Young people under the age of 21 commit 45% of



rapes, 44% of robberies, and 37% of other assaults,



and it is estimated that 50% of violent crime is alcohol related".
http://camy.org/research/underage2004/re...
The research findings on the subject in the UK and the USA are virtually identical.



</additional details>



<answer from>



annie]
Member since: 15 June 2008
Total points: 5988 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Of course it does.  Alcohol is one of the worst drugs (yes, I said it... drugs) that is legal and readily available to all who are overage (or for those who have older brothers, sisters, friends, and sometimes even parents willing to buy it for them).



Alcohol causes people to act a way in which they ordinarily wouldn't.



I have been drunk and have done some things that I could never ever do when I am sober.  Drinking causes people to lose all of their inhibitions... they are usually no longer able to tell the difference between right and wrong and this causes some of them (a lot, actually) to commit violent crimes.



Great point made in asking this question.



</answer>



<asker's comment>

Exactly.



</asker's comment>

<answer>



Hmmm, it's something I'd like to give more study time to, certainly.



In some ways, *anecdotally* I do think it's a bit of a toss-up ... I have known people who have used alcohol to 'get fuelled up' for something they already have in mind, and have also seen people behave incredibly atypically 'under the influence', as well as people who are fine after one or two drinks but don't seem to have an 'off' switch until they are almost comatose.



It might depend on the person, BUT there is also a large body of evidence nowadays about the 'inheritance' effects of alcohol, particularly where both parents are heavy drinkers.



Perhaps that does cause a kind of 'warp' that brings out the darker side of someone when alcohol is in question.



Probably because alcohol has been around in human society so long, most people regard it with a kind of familiar contempt ~ a good friend but a bad master kind of thing.



The fact is, however, that we DO know that alcohol is an incredibly powerful drug and the effects of taking it are not predictable from person to person, or situation to situation.



More study needed, definitely.



Cheers :-)



</answer>

Social Science

<question from>



csmiles
Member since: 31 October 2008
Total points: 100 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What is the best way to summarize the three waves of the feminist framework?



I need to do a class presentation on the feminist framework/theory and am struggling summarizing the "three waves" that some authors talk about.  Also any ideas on a class activity to help teach/understand the theory would be helpful.



</question>



<answer from>



Laughing...
Member since: 11 June 2007
Total points: 9138 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Wednesday, May 16, 2007
Three Waves Of Feminism
On a forum that I moderate and in which I have (proudly) become known as the resident radical feminist, another member asked me to elaborate upon the "waves" of feminism to which I frequently refer in my postings there. Since most people do not take courses in Women's Studies, Equity Studies or another social science and therefore may not have the background, here is a short and non-academic summary of the three distinct feminist movements of the 20th century.



The First Wave: This era of feminism lasted from about 1900-1920. It is characterized by the suffragette movement which was concerned primarily with women obtaining the right to vote, rather than having their political preferences represented by their husbands/fathers. Other aspects of this era of feminism include causes we would now consider "right-wing", that is, anti-abortion and for prohibition of alcohol. Don't let groups like this fool you; Susan B. Anthony and the others who were against abortion opposed it because it would allow men to have extramarital affairs and keep them secret (since in this pre reliable birth control era, babies were a frequent product of extramarital unions), rather than due to some perceived personhood bestowed upon the unborn fetus. These women opposed alcohol because their husbands often "drank away" their paycheques thus depriving the woman of income with which to care for (often numerous) children.



The Second Wave: This era began around the same time as the Civil Rights movement in the US, and occurred throughout the 1960s-1970s. This is the era of Gloria Steinem, Germaine Greer and Simone de Beauvoir - the one that my mother was raised on. Bra-burning has become a symbol of this supposedly "radical" brand of feminism - a feminism which asked for women's work both in and outside of the home to be recognized as equal to that of men, and asked for a woman's right to sovereignty over her own body. The pivotal 1973 case of Roe v. Wade in the US ushered in a new era of women's reproductive rights, while Our Bodies, Ourselves taught women what they didn't learn in Biology 101 about their genitals and how to enjoy them. This era of feminism has been critiqued for its privileging of white middle class womens' needs over those of others, which is what led to...



The Third Wave: This era began during the 1980s and is arguably the one in which we currently live. In response to concerns raised by groups like the Combahee River Collective (their statement can be found here) that the movement was not meeting the needs of women of colour, lesbian women, transgendered women, disabled women, and working class women among others, the feminist movement as it had been known until this point began to splinter and separate into several smaller groups, many of which formed and pursued its own specific mandate and cause. The idea of the "universal sisterhood", of all women sharing a bond and common interest inherent to their gender was seriously questioned since the most visible movers and shakers of the feminist movement up until this point had been white middle class women. Oppression between groups of women was explored, and the idea of "equality" was complicated so that it was no longer between "women" and "men", existing in a dichotomy of "good" and "bad". This era has been marked with major theoretical breakthroughs and the adoption of ideas like postructuralist theory in discussing and writing about feminism.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks so much..exsctly what I was trying to do but I was struggling with. Again thanks!!



</asker's comment>



<answer from>

<answer>



Actually, I think the 'three waves' is a misrepresentation of the women's movement.



There never has been a time when everything stopped and waited for a new 'wave'.



There have been times when there is less public activity and action, and times when there is more.



Women's lives are not linear and neither is the women's movement.



But y'know, that's just me.



For a scholarly look at the concept of 'three waves', try the links below.



Cheers :-)

http://209.85.173.104/search?q=cache:5nR...



http://books.google.com.au/books?id=zLcg...

<answer>



This question pops up in the R&S section quite often.



Personally, I think that abortion is misused. Although a woman should be allowed to make decisions about her own body, it should be taken into consideration that during an abortion, the fetus has no say in the ending of its own life. The fetus is killed in a most brutal and painful fashion. (Yes, a fetus can register pain.) Often, abortion is done out of a fear of ones parents finding out, at the insistence of the pregnant women's partner, or because they feel unable to go ahead with a pregnancy at this stage in their life. Others are, as you rightly pointed out are the victims of rape. Either abortion or carrying the child to term would be torture for the woman involved. Abortion is also used when there is a severe risk to the life of the mother (no right or wrong answers here) and when the fetus has a severe disability that would cause it much undue suffering (again, no right or wrong answers).



Adoption, although traumatic, is a kinder, solution.



However, any women making the decision has the right to end her pregnancy in a safe sterile environment. And at the end of the day, an abortion is a personal decision that will cause much hardship for the persons involved, regardless of the outcome.



</answer>

I've heard lots of black people share this same account...



Is it really a coincidence or is race involved?

<answer>



I am not sure.  I am white.  I have one friend from childhood, the rest are all from college or thereafter.



I am sure you did face some discrimination, but I would really look to see if these things you say happened really "seemed" (as you put it) to happen or actually did. This can be very difficult to do on an objective level...perhaps think about what you and these other girls did and what the punishments were.  Were the punishments fair?  Were your punishments harsher?  Did you ever give people reasons to blame you and these other girls did not give people reasons to blame them?  Maybe the opposite?  Then analyze to see if there would be a logical reason behind it (like reputations if dealing with peers)..if not, you have your answer.  I hope this is coincidence, but I am not sure if it is.



</answer>

Member since: 08 November 2007

<answer>



It's possible that race is involved on some level.



Racism goes a lot deeper than most of us realise, not just in ourselves but in society.



Recently I was at a formal dinner with some people I have known since childhood, who are great friends of another close family member.



During the dinner a particular political issue came up, and the husband said "Oh because of your background you will naturally think this way".



I was so surprised I couldn't even reply. Not only had he read the situation completely incorrectly regarding my opinion, but I was really hurt that he would think I thought a certain way based on my cultural background.



Sadly, this is an elderly guy who believes with all his heart that he is a fair and non-prejudiced person, and he is also a nice man with friends from many backgrounds who has been good to people in many ways.



So yeah, racism can hide out in many ways and come up when you least expect it. I'm sure your friends would deny they are racist to you, and probably truly believe they are not. And maybe they AREN'T.



If you want to remain friends with them you have to keep working on being a friend, and see where it takes you. Or find some other friends, in which case, you'll never REALLY know.



Best wishes :-)



</answer>



<answer from>



towerclo...
Member since: 05 October 2008
Total points: 412 (Level 2)

<answer>



Maybe, maybe not. If race is/was on your mind, either thinking it was their reasons for doing what they did in blaming you, or if it was their reason, then yes, it's involved. But if it was never a thought, or never influenced yours or their feelings about you or a situation, then no. At my school, we (unfortunately) end up having a natural segregation. It's not that the white kids only like white kids or the other way around - you just hang with whom you're the most comfortable with. I've got some black friends that I adore. :)



It could just be that you grew apart and didn't really have anything in common with them any more. It happens. Even if it wasn't racist, it could have been more cultural. Not every black person with white friends is an oreo, you know?



(Not that they should or shouldn't be. )



But maybe that's what happened. I wouldn't dwell too much on it, just the same. Focus on the future and the now.



</answer>



<answer from>



shebs
Member since: 07 February 2008
Total points: 10263 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



I had a similar situation, I was a member of a group that was mostly white, some Asian and with me being one of the white people.  One of our friends was from Ethiopia, and he, after a while, was regularly making statements and comments that showed he was insecure in a group of non-black people.  Topics always turned to race, and how black people were opressed.  We live in Australia, and the history of black slavery never happened here.  Black Africans are a significant minority where I live, but it is not as if we have had anything compared to what black people in the US have been through.



Anyway, he left our group after a while, sort of drifted away.  I ran into him a few years back and we talked over this issue, and he told me he had been under pressure from other black friends of his, and he had begun to think f us as complacent, and ignorant of racial issues.  It was certainly true that we were not focused on racial issues as a group, as we were mainly a social grouping.



He did admit he found it hard amongst the Asians in the group because he felt they had it easier than him somehow and he did come to realise, after a time, that it was not any of us that caused him to drift away, it was his own insecurity.



The point he made to me was that race was an issue: he made his own race the issue, not any of us, and he did regret it.



Your situation might be similar.  Look carefully at how you behaved among these people.  Friends who get a chip on their shoulder (not necessarily consciously) about an issue like race are hard to hold onto: they can alienate themselves.  This might not sound PC, but a lot of ethnic minority members make it hard for themselves.  No mistake, white people do it too, but it is more common in ethnic minorities associating with a stronger (in their eyes) minority or the ethnic majority.



</answer>
